output: Mr. President, firstly, I would like to congratulate Mr. Siebeck on the work carried out, as his report incorporates many of the concerns expressed in this...
Focusing on these crucial issues for the entire European Union. These are water scarcity and drought, matters that have already ceased to be solely a problem of the countries in Southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections made in the opinion report, for which I was the rapporteur in the Agriculture Committee, in favor of agricultural activity, emphasizing, for example, the role played by farmers in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that exacerbate raw material prices, an aspect that, in today's world, I also deem it crucial to highlight, so that we bear in mind not only the environmental dimension of this issue but also some of its most significant economic consequences.

The Environment Committee, moreover, included the idea of creating a European Drought Observatory, an action that is mentioned in the report of the Agriculture Committee itself, and which I hope will one day be reflected in concrete actions.

The text to be voted on tomorrow, however, does not include a proposal made by the Agriculture Committee to explore the implementation of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to advocate for the establishment of this fund, an idea that I will once again propose to Parliament when it receives, in the coming months, the communication that the Commission plans to publish on adapting to climate change.

It seems to me that, following the establishment of the Solidarity Fund, which was created to mitigate the losses caused by climate-related disasters, it is now time to consider an instrument that acts a priori and is designed to finance preventive measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of such climate catastrophes.
Atlético Madrid, its fans, and even the Spanish police are being mistreated by the European Football Federation.
But the case goes beyond the particular, as these federal bodies exacerbate penalties for those who resort to ordinary justice.
This medieval conception, this funnel law, is incompatible with the law, with European institutions, from which we must react.

And we will end up doing it, for these medieval gentlemen, arbitrary in their use of the gallows and the knife, must fall in line with respect for the law and the ordinary procedural guarantees of our Europe.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, terrorism is a global phenomenon and so is the action of serious organized crime. Therefore, the means employed must be proportional and effective in combating these threats.

I have taken careful note of the answers you have given to the questions that were pertinent. It is true that guarantees must be demanded, it is true that this is a sensitive matter, but it is no less true that it is absolutely inexcusable not to develop and formulate a global and harmonized response.
For some, terrorism seems a distant concern; they are more preoccupied with individual liberties.
I am concerned about both individual and collective efforts, and it is absolutely necessary that we start from wherever we can.
If we have started with air transport, where companies already have that data, let's start there.

Let us demand guarantees, let's see what the scope of application is, let's start with international transport relations, and beware, we will have to continue with internal ones because terrorists often do not come from outside, but from within.
Let them ask the United States and let them ask the others, for this is how it is and how we will have to approach it.
Mr. President, I would like to thank the Commission for presenting this proposal.
I believe this is a positive proposal and will help us reduce unnecessary administrative burdens.
Now, as the speakers who have preceded me have said, this Parliament has the obligation to ground what are very generous and altruistic proposals from the Commission.

And the reality is that there is a national reality in which there are twenty-seven countries with different legal systems and very distinct languages, which requires that in each of those countries we adapt to the country's realities, including the issue of languages.

Specifically, as Gosset has just pointed out and as previous speakers have emphasized, it is crucial that the recognition of these national specialties does not result in increased costs, that fees remain uniform, and that governments ultimately bear this additional cost.
But there is another topic that also arises, and it is the subject of translations.
Specifically, in the European Union we do not have a common language.

In the twenty-seven countries, very different languages are commonly spoken from one another; even in some countries, such as the Commissioner's, multiple languages are spoken, and we live with this reality.
And from a legal standpoint, moreover, we encounter the reality that legal documents are different.
The Legal Commission has proposed, for example, amendments regarding the authentication of minutes and documents, along with the authentication of translations.
At this time, the Committee on Legal Affairs is preparing a report on the recognition of authentic acts in various countries of the European Union, which should be complementary to this report.
Ultimately, I believe that the Commission has done well in presenting this report.
The rapporteur has done magnificent work, and I believe we have all strived to create a proposal for legislative text that can be recognized across the Union, ensuring human rights.
rights, based on the reality of a union that is being constructed, with different national legal systems and varying levels of access to electronic communication.

Mr. President, a large majority of farmers and livestock farmers are awaiting previous decisions and agreements that the Council of Agriculture Ministers of the Union will adopt today and tomorrow on this Union check.

the CAP, because it is not just a mere review, but it will bring about profound changes, such as the disappearance of many farms, if this cut proposed by the European Commission on direct aids goes ahead.

Modulation is the central focus of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of Parliament's opinion to have any impact on the negotiations being conducted by the Union's Ministers of Agriculture.
We have been opposing for years any increase in what we euphemistically call modulation, because if the rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is not...
due not to a lack of resources within the CAP's expenditure ceiling, but to an absolute absence of political will to provide the Community budget with this necessary pillar development.
Do they want to liberalize the markets?
Of course, do so, but with equal requirements and conditions for all producers, both within and outside the Union.

At this juncture, the European Union is deciding the future of many farmers and livestock breeders, and I would particularly like to draw attention to vulnerable sectors such as sheep, cattle, and tobacco farming, whose survival in many production areas will depend on this health check.

Some producers, such as those in the sheep sector, are no longer asking for aid, but simply want to be allowed to leave the market with dignity, because they have done the calculations and the only way to survive is to reduce production volumes.

The abandonment of production, therefore, is the only option we leave to many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be filled by imports from third countries, because the consumer will not stop consuming and the world will continue to increase the number of consumers at an unprecedented rate.
The Parliament should issue a prudent opinion, and the Council should heed it.

I would like to thank the Chair of the Agriculture Committee here for the efforts made by Mr París to ensure that the Parliament is heard and not blatantly ignored by the Council and the Commission, as has been the case up until now.
Mr. President, firstly, let me add my congratulations to the rapporteur, Mr. Capulas Santos, for his magnificent work.
I believe you have found balance and moderation in your report.
I believe that at this stage of the debate, it is crucial to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.
Sufficient transitional periods are necessary, as well as maintaining specific measures that are required for sectors in distress.
Madam Commissioner, not all sectors can be treated with the same solutions.
And we must remember that we have sectors that are facing genuine difficulties.
The common agricultural policy should not be the problem, but the solution, and for that, we need a strong first pillar.
We believe in and support rural development, but we do not think that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not a matter of strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that there is a need to simplify the single payment scheme, and to review market instruments.
But that does not mean dismantling them.
If we do this right, we will be laying the foundations for a common agricultural policy beyond 2013. If not, we will be putting an end to the activity of many European farmers.
We are facing a plan that has been greatly anticipated by the horticulture sector, not only due to the difficulties it is facing but also because of the concerning decline in consumption.
what we are faced with is a public health promotion plan. I believe it should be a European plan, and I also support full Community funding.

I disagree with allowing parents to contribute to the co-financing, because the same old thing will happen. Parents who can contribute money will have their children consuming fruits and vegetables in schools, while those who cannot will be left out of the program.
I believe it must be a community-funded plan for its distribution to be homogeneous.
Therefore, I also want to strongly emphasize that the focus should be on educational measures.

It is not merely about a student eating an apple, but rather that they know what type of apple they are consuming, understand its nutritional properties, and comprehend the beneficial effects that such fruit has on their health and development.

Of course, these should be products with all quality guarantees, giving priority, if possible, to seasonal fruits and, whenever feasible, I advocate for the community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I believe that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I would like to congratulate the Commissioner, will be immediately apparent, of course, for the present and future health of our children and their education.

nutritional, but I also believe it is highly important for the fruit and vegetable sector, a productive sector that constitutes a true European cultural heritage, as thanks to it we can enjoy a balanced, healthy, and varied diet.
I believe it is worth betting on and investing in this fruit and vegetable distribution plan in our schools.
I believe the budget falls slightly short, because once again, I advocate for full Community funding for such an ambitious plan as this one.
Mr. President, I ask you not to include these first words, please, in the infernal machine of time.
My first words are to associate myself with the message of condolence expressed by this House to Mrs. Klaas and, above all, to congratulate the rapporteurs.
Now, indeed, I begin.

I congratulate the rapporteurs because with these two proposals we are taking a significant step towards a common immigration policy and are moving towards the promotion of legal immigration, a key pillar of the comprehensive approach we advocate.
The overarching rights framework and the single permit for residence and work for legal migrants should be extended to the greatest number of workers.
Therefore, socialists demand that no category of workers be excluded.
The so-called blue card provides an opportunity for emigrants to settle with their families and work in our countries.
it opens a unique door to twenty-seven labor markets.
Now, it is not only highly qualified workers who should enter through this door.
Therefore, we hope, Commissioner, that the Commission will soon present us with its proposals concerning the other job categories.
Ladies and Gentlemen, we must combat the brain drain.
This blue card must not become a passport that facilitates a hemorrhage of vital human resources from developing countries.
Therefore, from the Socialist Group, we propose that for every qualified professional who comes to Europe, we fund the training of a new professional in their country of origin.
Lastly, Europe must be an attractive destination, not only for talents coming from outside the Union, but also for our own.
In two thousand seven, nearly three hundred highly qualified Europeans left to work outside the Union.
Let us do everything in our power to keep them in the European House.
Madam Vice-President, do you think the proximity or distance of candidates from voters is related to the level of participation in European elections?
European. Do you agree that a state of forty-five million inhabitants should have only one electoral district for elections to the European Parliament?
European, what can the Commission do to ensure that States with larger populations can have constituencies that are closer to citizens?

Mr. President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I wish to express the most vigorous condemnation by my Group of the murders being committed in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or of a religion.

Specifically, the manner in which this atrocious murder was committed, we already know: a 13-year-old girl who is raped and then accused of adultery, and five men, if they can be called men, rush to stone her to death and even prevent anyone from trying to save her in a stadium filled with a thousand people.
This, coupled with the acts of piracy that have reached nearly a hundred ships hijacked off the coast of Somalia this year, constitutes an absolutely unacceptable humanitarian situation.
The international community cannot remain indifferent to this.
You cannot remain indifferent in the face of cowardice, of the religious invocation to commit atrocities.
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate Government of Somalia in regaining control of the entire country and in establishing a rule of law that respects human rights.
I believe that on few occasions have we been presented with a situation so clear and one that imposes such obligations upon us.
I do not believe that we can remain impassive in this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in that situation.
I don't know how it can be done, but I certainly believe that it must be done and that quick action is necessary.
The Socialist Group does not agree with the amendments that were submitted at the last minute, which were not negotiated at the appropriate time.

We support the text of the joint resolution and hope that this marks the beginning of greater concern by the European Union for this type of humanitarian issue and for the rejection of the abusive use of religious concepts to commit atrocities in the name of God.
I believe that the rapporteur and the speakers who have preceded me have highlighted the characteristics of this proposal for a directive from the Parliament and the Council.
This is about recognizing that arms and ammunition are also part of the internal market, although, of course, with a series of limitations.
This is not about ordinary goods, they are not candies nor are they entertainment items, but rather objects that require precise control.
Certainly, there are limitations within the Treaty itself, in Article Thirty and Article Two Hundred and Ninety-Six, which bestow upon States significant responsibilities in this matter.
And the fact that we have a common market does not preclude States from being obligated to comply with security standards and, rightfully, to enforce them when their own security is at risk.

The work carried out in the Committee on Legal Affairs and in the committees that have collaborated with it, in accordance with the Council, under the expert guidance of the rapporteur, Ms. Ruile, has been very positive.
I believe that the text we are presenting today is a rather balanced one.

Essentially, although on paper there appear to be many amendments, today we are limited to a single amendment, which is Amendment 63, the one that captures the spirit of compromise. This amendment contains a well-articulated, coherent text that will enable the functioning of this entire market.
Mr. Tubón has emphasized that this is in line with other international texts.

For example, the adoption this very month of the Oslo Convention, the signing of the Oslo Convention on the Prohibition of Cluster Munitions, as well as the Convention on the Restrictions of Anti-Personnel Mines, and a whole series of international agreements and even European Union regulations aimed at limiting the use of weapons.
I believe that our model is not one of the free circulation of arms at any time, but rather a regulated market, controlled by states and also, from now on, by the European Union's own institutions.
Madam President, Commissioner, this proposal emerged from the Commission over a year ago, with some truly very ambitious objectives.

gradual reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and because it solved the old problem of vapor pressure for gasoline blends with bi-alcohol in countries like mine with warm summers.

Today, we have an agreement on the table that eases the enforcement of Article Seven-A and reinstates the waiver on vapor pressure, of course, tightening the conditions for accessing the exemption.
and that, as with the rest of this climate package, the agreement does not satisfy everyone one hundred percent, but is nevertheless acceptable to all.

Life expectancy is thirty-six years and more, yet only forty percent of the country's teachers are working, and only a third of students attend class, which means Mugabe is not only killing the present, he is killing the future.
The repression and mutilation of human rights are also commonplace.
Human rights defenders in Zimbabwe have been systematically targeted with arbitrary detentions, arrests, and torture.
The legislation introduced by the government severely curtails the freedoms of expression, assembly, movement, and association.
I would like to cite several of these cases, as the government has introduced increasingly repressive regulations, which have been used against these human rights activist defenders.

For example, the Access to Information and Privacy Protection Act, used by the Government to effectively silence journalists, the Public Order and Security Act, which has severely restricted the freedom of assembly, and hundreds of...

human rights defenders, including independent media workers, have been arbitrarily detained, and the Private Voluntary Organizations Law, reinstated by the government in 2002, has reportedly been used to intimidate and harass NGOs.
Madam President, in my native language, Basque (which is not official in this House), 'Mugabe' means 'without limit', a fitting nickname for this individual.

The dictator of this African country is not just another name on the unfortunately lengthy list of dictators that exist on our planet, but I venture to say that he holds one of the top ten positions in the ranking of dictators.
I believe that in the EU we must do everything in our power to ensure that this individual is brought to justice and spends their remaining days seated before a Human Rights Court.
We therefore wish Zimbabwe a happy year two thousand nine without Mugabe.
We have a resolution proposal on Nicaragua that requires addressing various aspects.
Firstly, there are allegations of fraud, at least in two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this taints the electoral results of November 9th.
On the other hand, we have a Government that has taken steps to address some of the issues that infringe on human rights in Latin America.
specifically poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, access to potable water, and the lack of land rights for indigenous peoples.
Then, when examining the case, we must clearly distinguish between the two aspects.

On the one hand, we have to promote human rights and defend them in the traditional sense as political rights, and on the other, we must encourage the Government of Nicaragua, continuing in its role of assisting the most needy sectors of the country.
Of course, we must ensure that the opposition can fulfill its role, we must oppose fraud, but we must also defend the actions of NGOs.
However, nevertheless, one must achieve a balanced result.
The Socialist Group has tabled several oral amendment proposals, aiming to steer the final text towards a more balanced stance regarding the allegations.
fundamental rights violations, regarding the criminal or non-criminal nature of the investigations and concerning the number of municipalities in which some form of revocation has occurred.

In a nutshell, we aim to condemn the alleged violations of fundamental political rights, but without going to the extreme of placing the Government of Nicaragua in a difficult position to continue fulfilling its role of supporting the most needy sectors of society.
On the situation created in Nicaragua by the attacks against some human rights defenders, against certain fundamental freedoms, and against democracy.

There is no need to recall here and now Zoila América, Ernesto Cardenal, Carlos Mejía Godoy, Jarquín, Sergio Ramírez, or the many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.
In November of two thousand and six, Mr. Ortega requested and obtained, democratically, from Nicaraguans what he called a new opportunity.
Today we already know what she wanted it for.
Since then, arbitrariness, nepotism, and corruption have taken root in government institutions, culminating in the electoral fraud of the November 9th elections.

Previously, very serious decisions had been made, such as the cancellation of the legal personality of certain opposition parties, threats and intimidation against members of civil society, journalists, and media outlets.
President Ortega described the governments of the European Union as flies buzzing around filth and characterized the foreign aid received by Nicaragua as crumbs.
He soon realized that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to do without that development aid.

As we prepare to enter a decisive phase in the negotiation of an association agreement between the European Union and Central America, the Government of Nicaragua should know that it will always find in us an ally and a friend.

but for us, the demand for respect for human rights, freedom of expression, and democracy, in short, is a condition to which we do not renounce because we believe that the people of Nicaragua benefit from it especially.
On November 9th, municipal elections were held in Nicaragua.

As on previous occasions, that electoral process has been called into question from the standpoint of democratic legitimacy, with accusations of fraud having been leveled and irregularities having occurred...
manifestations and clashes between supporters of different political parties, resulting in numerous injuries and a deepening of the political crisis that this country has been suffering.
Two political parties have been unable to register for the local elections, which is unacceptable as it curtails the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.

On the other hand, we have received direct testimonies from representatives of human rights organizations who have informed us about the existence of a questioning of the judicial system by civil society.

on the existence of administrative repression mechanisms that have brought as many as seventeen social movement organizations before the courts, on the persecution of independent journalists and even the delegation of the European Commission.

For all these reasons, we wish to raise our voice and make an appeal, firstly, to political parties to condemn acts of violence perpetrated by their followers, and secondly, to the government itself to reopen spaces for participation.

as a citizen, that freedom of expression be respected, that marches no longer be prohibited, and that all NGOs be able to receive assistance from international cooperation, not just those from Venezuela, for pro-government associations.
Similarly, they should repeal the penalization of therapeutic abortion in cases where the mother's life is in danger.

And finally, we also call on the Commission to ensure that the negotiations for the Association Agreement between Central America and the European Union remind Nicaragua of the need to respect the principles of the rule of law.

democracy and human rights, all without prejudice to the fact that from Europe we continue to provide our development and welfare assistance for the Nicaraguan people, whom we hope will have the best possible future.
Madam President, I am going to refer to the Breyer report.
I must say that European farmers are fully aware that when using plant protection products, particular attention must be paid to human health as well as to environmental protection.
However, the sector is deeply concerned that the European Parliament does not understand the impact this Regulation could have in the future.
There are assessments of its potential impact that indicate that, due to the future scarcity of plant protection products, it will be very difficult to achieve the objective.
pest and disease control affecting the cultivation of a large number of food products, specifically all Mediterranean products, as well as the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.
I am fully aware that the agreement reached in the trilateral dialogue has been the result of arduous negotiations, and I must therefore acknowledge the work done by the rapporteurs.

However, it is important to consider that the temporal definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the elimination of a large number of active substances, particularly insecticides, that are of key importance to agriculture.

Producers must have access to a sufficient quantity of active substances to effectively and safely combat any plant disease or pest, taking into account that the hazard is often not in the product itself, but rather in its misuse.
For all these reasons, the Spanish delegation of the EPP Group in the EU supports the proposals requesting an impact assessment and will vote in favor of the amendments.
from Mr Stardy, which I myself have signed, concerning endocrine disruptors and those that facilitate the availability of plant protection products in emergency situations.

Furthermore, if this Regulation is adopted in the terms of the Agreement reached, the effects will be a reduction in food production and a rise in prices, leading us to import the very same foods we do not produce, treated with the products we are banning.
Mr. President, Mr. Capato, your report is brimming with good intentions. The most evident proof is that it did not warrant any amendments during its processing in the Committee on Civil Liberties.
It was you yourself who introduced eighteen amendments to your own report.
And those amendments are what have introduced, let's say, a certain radicalism into that report, in general terms, which raises very serious doubts for me.
I would propose, in four distinct categories, the amendments that you have put forward, which you yourself have raised, I insist, in a report that initially received the support of all groups.
Some are impossible. You are asking for things that are impossible.

For example, Mr. Capato, you are requesting things for which there is as yet no legal basis. For instance, until the Lisbon Treaty enters into force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of different committees.
something similar to what Commissioner Wallström just said. You are asking, for example, that we declare 2009 the year of transparency. We are late, there is no more time.
Therefore, you are asking for things that are impossible.
Moreover, it requests some other options that are not recommended.
For example, you request transparency in the meetings of political groups.
No, less.
that privacy is lacking. Privacy is a political good.
If I want to disagree with my party, to maintain an opposition, I want to do so in private, and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency should be demanded of public institutions, but not within political parties, where debates must be guaranteed in private.
Therefore, I cannot follow you on that point.
There are some other assertions you make, Mr. Capato, that are inaccurate.
For example, you say that ninety percent of legislative activity is due to comitology.
That is a reckless exaggeration, Mr. Capato.
Moreover, criminology inherently incorporates standards of transparency in and of itself.

If what we are going to do now is create more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be going against what we want to achieve, which is transparency—something that is very closely related to simplicity.
Lastly, before the president calls my attention, as I am already using up my time, there are some things that are unnecessary.
For example, I understand that it is very appealing and attractive to public opinion to call for transparency in the activity of deputies, to know that they attend the plenary sessions.
It is already known, Mr. Capato.
Those that go to the committees, it is already known if there is a record of all of them, are accessible acts for all citizens.
or the diets they charge for. You know, Mr. Capato.
In other words, it is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

Therefore, I understand that it is very popular with public opinion and that advocating for transparency is very appealing, but I want you to know that transparency means making things appear as they are. And when we contribute to things not being seen as they are, Mr. Capato, then we are not contributing to transparency.
Thank you for your generosity, Mr. President.

horror at the repeated scene of children killed and women torn apart in their infinite suffering after the bombings of the ghetto that Gaza has become.
the same horror that Picasso painted in his Guernica, our Guernica ravaged by the Junckers of the Condor Legion seven decades ago.
solidary pain with so many victims of so much suffering.
and shame for the inability of all, of our States, of the European Union, and of the international community, first to prevent and then to put an end to the criminal aggression that we denounce.
Shame and indignation at so much lying, so much ambiguity, and so much empty rhetoric.
Shame because we know exactly what is happening and we do not act with the necessary and demandable firmness and consistency.
Therefore, history will hold many accountable as accomplices to the crime, if nothing else, by omission.
Because better late than never, and because it is indispensable to keep a door open to hope, the European Union should support the belated Security Council resolution.

what must be strictly enforced, and our Association Treaty with Israel must be adhered to just as strictly, providing for its suspension in the face of conduct such as that which is currently occurring.

I would like to greet the few European cooperative youth who are suffering alongside the people of Gaza, in particular Alberto Arce.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, as we can see, in recent times the textile sector has been undergoing a significant crisis that has led to numerous company closures, relocations, and unemployment, with these events particularly concentrated in regions specialized in this activity.

In light of the current economic crisis situation, the European Commission should act swiftly alongside the Member States to mitigate the socio-economic effects of this restructuring, which is particularly dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I believe it is necessary to provide support to workers in the textile and clothing sector through social measures, and through plans for companies that are subject to restructuring and are currently in serious difficulties.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial portion of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to the restructuring and retraining of the textile sector.
in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, which make up the majority of the sector in the European Union and are most affected by the effects of market liberalization.
On the other hand, it is necessary to reestablish the control system for imports from abroad, and especially, given their volume, from China.
It is not at all about promoting trade barriers.

It is a matter of compensating for the negative effects of such a significant transformation. We must also remember that the European Union is the world's second-largest exporter of textiles and clothing products.

In other words, this makes it necessary to ensure the best possible conditions of access to third country markets, which are essential for the future of the textile and clothing industry based in the European Union and, in particular, for SMEs.
All this, of course, while always ensuring fair competition based on the promotion of environmental and social standards in these countries.

In this regard, publishing correct information to consumers, for example, through the regulation on the Made in designation, which to our knowledge has not been implemented, would be of great use since.
among other things, would involve subjecting imported products to the same safety and consumer protection requirements as those manufactured within the European Union.

We should also consider the possibility of accepting prisoners from countries where human rights are not guaranteed, even if the United States does not request it.

Mr. President, in the EU there are various cases of languages belonging to historic European peoples who, due to not being constituted as a state, are not allowed to be used in the debates of this Parliament. This represents a democratic and representative deficit.

One of these cases is that of the Basque language, Euskera, which is not a minority language but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which administratively falls within the Spanish state.

But the same does not happen, and do not take it personally, Commissioner, with Northern Basque Country, part of the French State, whose President, before the United Nations Assembly, affirmed that denying respect for national identities and languages is to fuel humiliation, and that without such respect, there will be no peace in the world.
And then, neither Basque, nor Corsican, Breton, or Occitan have the slightest official recognition or support to respect or promote their use.

Therefore, I call on the Fundamental Rights Agency to monitor and work towards ensuring that within the Member States, the rights of the mother tongue of no European people are violated, nor are their inhabitants discriminated against, and that all of them are considered official within their respective territories.
Skerry Casco, Jan Andreok, Suel Laguncha Gaitik, Europe Co., and Skuncha Agustín Alde.

Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his great work in achieving a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our House.
With this Directive, we once again demonstrate our commitment to building a common migratory policy based on a comprehensive approach.
The approach of this Directive is clear: to combat organized crime, punish unscrupulous employers, and protect exploited immigrants who lack any form of social protection.
We want the unjust low wages for immigrants to disappear, and also, those that distort average salaries, especially in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, or hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and large amounts of money involved in the shadow economy.
In precisely difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently, with generosity but also with responsibility.
The easy option would be to give in to the temptation of not attempting to curb the shadow economy.
We cannot turn a blind eye and leave around eight million irregular immigrants in a state of vulnerability, with working conditions akin to slavery.

Ladies and Gentlemen, if we want this Directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic and even criminal sanctions in the most aggravated cases are necessary, which have a dissuasive effect on entrepreneurs.
By doing so, we will manage to reduce the shadow economy and eliminate the migratory incentive created by the possibility of working illegally.
It must be made clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal route.
Therefore, we wish to pursue the global approach and call on the Commission, Commissioner, Mr Baró, to present the new "blue cards," as soon as possible, for the other employment categories.
Dear colleagues, Ms Ferrero-Waldner, Mr Solana, firstly, I would like to thank the three rapporteurs for their work. As the shadow rapporteur for the report on CSDP, I will address
In this specific report, I begin by congratulating Mr. Saris Volski on the outcome of his work and the collaboration offered by the other groups to achieve a consensual result.

In the same way that this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to be equipped with the necessary instruments to speak with one voice in the world, the Chamber itself is also capable of showing cohesion around the assessment and promotion of the major priorities in foreign policy and the common security policy.

Our group's commitment, the Socialist Group, has been directed towards a dual objective. On one hand, we have sought to introduce or strengthen major issues that are key for us across the entire realm of foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of...

peace across the entire planet or a commitment to human development. On the other hand, to propose elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the CSDP as they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared at all, or to introduce them as a new element if they were absent.
In this way, we have advocated, for instance, for a greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the recently defined Eastern dimension.

We have advocated for greater diversification and enhanced relevance in our relations with Africa, a continent we often only remember when particularly vicious wars break out, and even then, not always.

In relation to Latin America, we have sought to reflect the current negotiation processes of association agreements, the first of a biregional nature that the European Union will conclude in its entire history.

As for the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that speaks only of security, in order to include, instead, the entire rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained within the Barcelona Process.

As for amendments for the plenary session, our group has not tabled any, believing that the balance achieved through the compromises is thereby strengthened. Consequently, we will oppose most amendments to avoid undermining the compromise reached in the Foreign Affairs Committee.
Mr. President, the Venezuelan referendum has resulted in a victory for the 'yes' vote, gracefully acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that there has not been equal opportunity in the campaign and that the ruling party has enjoyed overwhelming support from the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under those conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not through visceral attitudes, disparagement, or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralistic, and free path.
In that regard, we criticize the Venezuelan government's decision to expel a Spanish MEP, and even more so the manner in which such expulsion was carried out. However, we call on this House to avoid

that our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate local laws and regulations, and even less that they insult a head of state, no matter how much they may be open to criticism.
With these attitudes, we are compromising future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.

Mr. President, I have just returned from Venezuela, where I was invited by its electoral authority as a member of an international electoral accompaniment group for the referendum held on the 15th of last month.

The European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council, providing an overall positive assessment of the process in terms of its organization, transparency, participation, the free and secret exercise of the right to vote, and security throughout all its stages.

Regarding the statements made by Deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, he noted that they sought to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, leveled serious accusations against the democratic institutions of that country, and bordered on interference in the internal politics of a sovereign nation.
Our Parliament should not encourage any kind of confrontation with Venezuela's democratic institutions.
On the contrary, it would be incumbent upon the honorable member to provide explanations to this House regarding an action that affects us all.
The Budget Committee considers it of the utmost importance to clearly define each of the budgetary instruments.
Therefore, the most realistic option appears to be the creation of a new instrument for actions other than public development aid to countries falling within the scope of that Regulation.
From a budgetary standpoint, the proposal for funding from the Development Commission seems inappropriate, as that money does not exist.
not counting those lines with a multi-year allocated credit. There is a credit for two thousand nine, but not beyond that.
In any case, since the financing of this new cooperation instrument must be consistent with the 2007-2013 financial framework, it is appropriate
recall the importance of the intermediate review of the financial framework, which should allow for an adjustment of the ceilings of the various headings.
Madam President, at this late hour on Monday, the Commission probably has other things that concern it more than this report.
In essence, what we are doing is simply responding to a Commission report, a report on the implementation of Regulation 1206-2001.
Council of May 28, 2001, on cooperation between the judicial authorities of the Member States in the field of obtaining evidence in civil or commercial matters.
We are in a realm that is truly non-community, it is an intergovernmental sphere, in which the Council, through the Regulation, has sought to stimulate cooperation among these judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

In other words, certain measures have been foreseen, for example, the issuance of practical guides, the use of electronic means, etc., but I acknowledge that it is quite difficult for the Commission to take action.

I do not know what the Commission has achieved or intends to achieve, but it seems to me quite difficult to accomplish due to the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation presents.

In other words, we are asking judicial authorities to collaborate with each other; we are talking about 27 countries, with judicial authorities handling 22 different languages, and very distinct legal systems. We are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a significant delay in these cooperation mechanisms, and certainly, that we do not have the means to carry them out.
Ideally, one would have material resources.
For example, what could the Commission do to provide judicial bodies, especially those at a lower level, with technological tools such as a videoconferencing system?
Videoconferencing may be a utopian ideal for many small courts across the European Union, but it appears to be the only way to achieve this.
I believe that the European Union should rely on already existing institutions, specifically the European Judicial Network.
We would need to strengthen this institution so that judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, any training for judges is fundamental.
This is something the Commission cannot do on its own either.
However, the Commission can encourage the development of this type of training course in community law and in the knowledge of different legal systems.
Then there is a huge difficulty, which is the problem of languages, that is, how can, say, a Spanish judge communicate with a Finnish judge with two such different languages.
It is not reasonable to expect judges, in addition to having to navigate their own legal system, which is already quite complex in itself, to be required to have knowledge of this type of matter.
What can we do from a practical standpoint to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?
translation, that is, what could we do to help them do it?
in presenting this report, to exhibit any rigor or harshness towards the Commission.
I believe the work is quite challenging.
What I would like to know, taking advantage of the fact that we have a commissioner here who is interested in this topic, is what the commission thinks can be done to provide greater...

strict adherence to this regulation of the year two thousand and one, which is somewhat imprecise, somewhat voluntarist, and I don't know if from a practical point of view it can have any consequences or if progress can be made with it.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislative term with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in the year nineteen hundred and ninety-nine, we suffered a major maritime accident, that of the Erika vessel, near the French coasts, which gave its name to a first set of legislative proposals aimed at curbing and preventing accidents.
We believed we had averted the danger, but soon after, the coasts of Galicia were ravaged by the oil slick from another accident, even greater than the first, involving a ship.

Since then, in the Transport Committee, we have been working on successive legislative packages, attempting to overcome the numerous resistances we encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States that rejected our proposals, considering them too demanding.

In these ten years, we have adopted various Directives and Regulations, some of which we have had to revise again because, due to the cuts promoted by the Council, they were not effective in their original formulation.

We approved the rules for the introduction of double-hull ships, the European Fund for major oil catastrophes, refuge ports, and now we are reviewing and approving the liability of passenger carriers by sea, the investigation of

maritime accidents, the community system for monitoring and information on maritime traffic, port state control, and finally, the regulation and directive concerning ship inspection and recognition organizations.
And all of this is good and desirable to be able to enter into force and be applied by all member states in the shortest possible timeframe.
That is why I feel satisfied.
But the legislative term ends, I leave Parliament, and I do so with the regret of not having succeeded in making the introduction of existing control systems mandatory.
are patented to know when and how many bilge and fuel tank residues have been illegally discharged into the sea by a particular ship.
that is, a kind of black boxes or tachometers that can be inspected by maritime authorities each time a ship arrives in port.

I believe we owe the marine environment better care and stricter procedures to curb the vast amount of pollution we produce. If we fail to do so, it will impact our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that it will not take another decade to achieve more effective and efficient control over illegal marine spills.
Mr. President, the revision of the Eurovignette Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and affects us all, especially the peripheral countries, who feel victimized by this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to tackle the internalization of the external costs of road transport by attributing three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

While the principles inspiring the proposal "he who uses pays" and "he who pollutes pays" are reasonable, the proposed solution is by no means so, as it will be discriminatory towards a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing road freight transport, even if it was not the intention, has turned out to be the outcome.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is ill-timed and, far from achieving the desired goals of sustainable transport, would be a death sentence for a large number of European small and medium-sized enterprises that employ thousands of people.

persons in the European Union and contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their end consumer, a consumer who will see their products become more expensive due to the application of these tariffs.

Ladies and gentlemen, we need a competitive, sustainable, and environmentally-friendly transport system, without overlooking the road network, because currently it is the only way to reach everywhere.
Modal change remains a dream, far from becoming a reality.
Trans-European networks, motorways of the sea, cross-border connections remain, in some cases, projects rather than realities.
Ladies and Gentlemen, when the titanium of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to keep playing, let alone for joys.

Mr. President, the European Commission, on July 15, 2008, adopted a communication addressed to the Council and the Parliament, recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European Council on Foreign Relations recognized Mexico as a strategic partner on October 13th, pending the opinion of the Parliament on the matter.
Let us recall that already at the seventh meeting of the Joint Parliamentary Committee between the European Union and Mexico, held at the end of October last year, we stated that one...
This strategic association between Mexico and the European Union constitutes a necessary impetus to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We highlight the good moment in relations between both parties and the positive balance of the current Global Agreement.

We emphasize the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and cooperation matters, especially in the face of the new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis that is shaking our continents.

With the great country that Mexico is, we share values and goals such as the development of democratic forms of government, commitment to gender equity, consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.
We advocate for closer cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking, based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Accordingly, we are going to support the proposal for recommendations on the European Union-Mexico Strategic Partnership, which will be put before Parliament this very morning.
I would like, with regard to the report on microcredit, to congratulate all the rapporteurs, as they have done a great job.
have undoubtedly improved the Commission's initiative.
I understand that the recommendations set out here will enable us to lay the foundation for developing an authentic microcredit sector framework within the European Union.
which has been a success in many developing countries, including some European ones, both as an economic activity mechanism and as a tool to improve social inclusion and job creation.
but it has not been transferred to the community sector or context, and I believe this is an opportunity to do so, especially given the economic and financial context we are in.
priority, in that sense, is to strengthen the initiatives being advanced here, but more steps need to be taken.
There is a need to increase the funds available for this microcredit support structure.
We need to improve access for individuals and businesses that do not have access to loans, and in this regard, Madam President, I would like to highlight the example of
the European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate this access and which has been included in the report.
And I conclude by thinking that, without a doubt, this will lay the foundations for us to create a harmonious framework in the European context that will boost the microcredit sector.

Madam President, taking advantage of the fact that we are discussing the budget, I believe we must prepare ourselves for negotiations next year on the continuation of coal subsidies, an essential indigenous energy source.
And I say this with due advance notice because, inappropriately, some high-ranking official, confusing public opinion, was allowed to express a contrary view, leaking it to an economic publication.
None of that.
There will be a need to continue supporting my country's coal industry beyond 2012, and I would like this to be noted in the official record.
Limit yourselves, gentlemen, to adhering to the current plan and, from the year 2012 onwards, to the instrument we will begin negotiating with the sector next year.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Boclan has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the ship recycling convention to be held in May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr Brok, not only for the question but also for the Resolution he has prepared.

In the Popular Party, we are in favor of the fight against the bad practices and methods that have been used to dismantle ships, and therefore we support Mr. Brockland's resolution proposal. However, there are some points that concern us.

The first is section three, which he has also highlighted, stating that ships in their entirety should be considered hazardous waste and, consequently, should fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have tabled an amendment on this paragraph because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union, and we believe that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradicted. However, it should be the future international agreement on ship dismantling that defines the details of its implementation.
The proposed resolution also calls for, in its fourteenth point, a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

It seems to us to be somewhat premature to discuss mandatory contributions at this time when the IMO has yet to decide on the system to be adopted for this funding, and I also believe that the European Commission does not have a clear answer on this matter.
Finally, point fifteen urges the Commission to clearly establish that the state with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible state.
We also do not believe it is within the Commission's purview to make this decision, which should also be determined through an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure coherence between the future convention on ship recycling and the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal, taking into account not only the Basel Convention but also all existing legislation.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is to congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we share a great deal of agreement regarding this program, and to congratulate us all, because in times of economic crisis it is fundamental to maintain a program like this one, with clear positive social effects.

Although we are facing a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that, in these times of economic uncertainty, we are not exclusively concerned from Brussels and Strasbourg.

not only concerned with the recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those that support those most in need, the poorest in the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program should continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy, where we agree with the Commission, not only because European agriculture has a strong social dimension, but also because it is a functioning instrument, because it is now more necessary than ever, and because it should continue to operate.

From the Socialist Group, like the rapporteur, we are opposed to this program being confined to cooperation between the European Union and the Member States, as this would imply discrimination between countries based on their wealth, potentially resulting in the program not being implemented in the most needy nations.

It is not understood why, at a time when it is most needed, the Commission seeks to save Community funds in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budget surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full community funding is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries and, above all, those most in need.
Forty-three million potential beneficiaries of this program demand a greater effort from us and, under no circumstances, should there be any cuts to the budget.
Austerity, yes, but not at the expense of the poorest.
And it is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizen of all the Member States that the program must cover the entire journey of the food distributed.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have tabled an amendment to ensure that all expenses arising from distribution, including transport, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the rapporteur that food should preferably be community-sourced and of high quality.
This is the stance consistent with the position taken by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this House, such as the fruit distribution plan in schools.
Nothing more, and many thanks.

We hope that the Commission will take into account the position of this Parliament when the vote takes place and, above all, that the plan will be implemented in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile areas of our planet.
The consequences of unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic, not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The melting of vast areas has brought these risks to the forefront, making it necessary to establish new global regulations to protect the Arctic, similar to those already in place for Antarctica, while considering the differences that have been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty among all involved parties, undoubtedly including the European Union, is necessary to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable character of all types of human activities, and multilaterally regulate navigation through the new maritime routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, throughout its many years of existence, has been a model of cooperation in addressing shared challenges.

In these times of difficulty and uncertainty, we must elevate this spirit and this harmony to higher levels to prevent the states in the region or other international actors from engaging in geopolitical disputes, forgetting what should be the common goal: the preservation of a great shared heritage.
Mr. President, unlike the two speakers who have just preceded me, I agree with most of the contributors.
This is a good Directive, an excellent Directive, aimed at protecting interpreters.
When it is said that we need to find a smarter way of doing business, what is really being referred to is the abolition of intellectual property.
Because business can only be conducted when there is an established right.
We already have an established right at the national level.
The Commission, under the leadership of Mr. Macrivi, has adopted a bold initiative, a positive initiative, and I believe that the House should endorse the compromise we have reached.
achieved within the Committee on Legal Affairs thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr Crowley, and the various shadow rapporteurs, such as Ms McGill and Mr Tugong.
I believe it is an excellent directive, one that will enhance the creation of intellectual property.
Moreover, that Directive includes a few recommendations regarding the continuation of the work.

I believe that the approval of this report by this House, and I hope that the Council will align itself with the positions of the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament, will help to ensure that in the next parliamentary term, the...

The Commission should continue down this path, make proposals to Parliament, and make progress in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.

Mr. President, the information you provide me is correct, but the impression that European Parliamentarians, and ultimately European citizens, have is that we face a very dangerous gap in Community law.
At this time, as tax demands are strengthening in each of the member states, mobility is nearly impossible.
And when we ask the Commission, the reason for the pragmatic approach is that the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We find ourselves in a kind of vicious circle whereby the Commission refers us to the Council, and the Council refers us back to the Commission. Meanwhile, the reality is that citizens living in this Europe we seek to build do not have the possibility of living in different countries or establishing relationships due to the heavy tax burden that results from the lack of tax harmonization.
fiscal. Can the Council do something to help us break out of this vicious circle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that the President is not here, and that Mr Tajani has come, because Mr Tajani has the advantage of having been a Member of the European Parliament.
And as a European Parliamentarian, I know that you have experienced the frustration that we European Parliamentarians feel regarding the implementation of Community law.

Now, in Parliament, we tend to criticize the Commission. I believe we are asking the Commission for an impossible task, because all Community Law and its entire application are based on indirect implementation.

In other words, the Commission has only a handful of officials at its headquarters, where it receives some complaints and has some scope for action. However, at this time, there is also a tendency to limit budgetary powers, which means the Commission will not have the ability to act.
All Community law, the entire application of Community law, is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, and national officials.
And here, on this point, I do not think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we need to do is assist the Commission, and I believe that Mrs Frassoni's report contains some points that could be useful in achieving this implementation.
I am referring to those concerning the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments, and the action of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, during a mission led by my colleague from this group, Marian, I had the opportunity to visit.
Sierra Leone and of being present in this Court and being aware of the immense work it was carrying out, not only for Sierra Leone but for all of humanity.
The Special Court for Sierra Leone, as has already been stated here, has set a precedent.

A precedent because, as the Resolution rightly points out, it is the first international tribunal funded by voluntary contributions, it is the first tribunal established in the country where the alleged crimes took place, and it is also the first tribunal, as already noted, to try a former prime minister.

For all these reasons, not only because it sets a precedent, but also because it serves as a reference for other courts established under its auspices, such as those in Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, Cambodia, and Lebanon, we deem it indispensable to adopt this Resolution, on which we have been working jointly with the Court for several months.
Two years ago, we adopted a resolution to support its funding. Two years ago, the Court was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of...
money and did not have sufficient support. Here, we must also thank the European Commission for providing financial support for this Court.

Now we request, above all, two things first, that the convicted persons serve their sentences. What is at stake is not just the operation of the Court, which concludes next year, but the legacy this Court will leave us. Secondly, obviously, all this must be accompanied by increased funding.
In definitive, the Special Court of Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have judged war crimes.

He is an example and a reference, and he is a lesson being taught by the second poorest country on this planet, where, upon entering the Court, we saw a motto written on the wall that read: Without justice, there is no peace.
And precisely for that reason, we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans but as human beings, to ensure that the legacy of this Court remains permanently in history.

Mr. President, very briefly, which I am sure Members will appreciate at this hour, Mr. Vice-President of the Commission, many thanks once again, because you have demonstrated, as you did with the third package, your commitment.

maritime, whose momentum and political standing have been able to drive an agreement close to the Council and make it possible for Parliament, the Council, and the Commission to reach an agreement at this juncture and in these final days of the legislative term.
I believe we must congratulate ourselves
