I would like to express my gratitude, once again, for the work and collaboration of the shadow rapporteurs. Ultimately, I believe that adopting an agreement at first reading tomorrow on such an important regulation, which undoubtedly completes the work of the...

The third maritime package represents a success for this Parliament and for the European Union across its three institutions, and once again justifies the co-decision procedure, which is useful and enables constructive dialogue for the benefit of all citizens of the European Union.
I was just about to respond to Commissioner, who is aware of my friendship and affection for her, and indeed, of my friendship and affection for Mr Orban.
But the commissioner has not uttered a single word about the ombudsman's recommendation.
In other words, the Ombudsman, who is aware of all the arguments presented by the Commissioner, has made a precise recommendation that the Commission appears to be ignoring in its entirety.

I do not even want Mrs. Cuneva to reply to me, because evidently, she is not the one who has the data. However, all the data she has provided me with is consistent with what we already knew and with what the ombudsman also knows but is not telling us if it is indeed effective.

Despite all that, and as the ombudsman, who is aware of this, recommends that the rule be changed, he does not indicate whether the Commission will adopt what the ombudsman requests and what the Parliament recommends based on the ombudsman's request.

Mr. President, I believe that the regulatory proposals submitted to us by the Commission are important and necessary, and on the other hand, it was also important and necessary that from the outset, we establish a clear framework for the use of artificial intelligence.
European Parliament, we insisted on the principles emphasized by the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, Mr Svieska and Mr Depré, namely the principle of Community competence.

This is a matter of shared competence between the Community and the Member States, where, for practical reasons, it is advisable to maintain certain competences of the States, but, as Mr. Barró has stated, these should be limited in scope and duration.
Community competence is non-negotiable, and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor Parliament have the authority to relinquish these community competencies.

With this established, it is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, and which I think will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow for the adoption of this package of measures at first reading.

But I also hope that, on the part of the Commission, from now on and building on this, we can make progress in the development of a genuine European private law, which is increasingly necessary, as has been highlighted, for example, by Mr Sogor in his last speech.
We are discussing the problems that most directly affect people, and to the extent that we are able to resolve these issues for the people, they will realize that the European Union has a role.

In conclusion, Mr. President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr. Debrey and Mr. Svieska, and thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this matter.

Madam President, Commissioner, I have signed this Resolution and have requested to speak on this matter because I was a witness to what was called an expulsion, but in reality was the kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrero.

Furthermore, I was able to verify that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, aggressor intimidation, threats, contempt for the dignity of individuals, and the tortuous use of justice, among other things, are common practices in Venezuela.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel's back and has led to this Resolution, but there are thousands of cases as egregious as his that are cited in the Resolution and others that are not.
as is the case of Ligio Cedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well-known for its danger and, moreover, because it elected a mayor who was not from the Chavista regime.

Eligio studied with the help of others, and specifically with support from Citibank, he was able to found his own business, the Banco de Caracas. Moreover, he later lived a normal life, aiding those most in need.
Today, however, he languishes in an illegal Caracas prison, having been detained for two years without any coherent charges.
Their only crime is being part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Nilson Moreno, student leader at the University of the Andes, elected several times to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
In two thousand three, he won the elections for the current Interior and Justice Minister, and this is his crime.
Today he is accused of attempted homicide, violent lascivious acts, and all this despite having been exonerated of those same accusations.

Situations like yours are an everyday occurrence in this country, where the persecution of opponents with the intent to exclude them from political life and discourage dissent has become a part of daily life.

However, from here, it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy. Despite the difficulties, I am certain that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be removed from office through the ballot box.
Madam President, Commissioner, it is indeed undeniable that progress has been made in recent times, but despite all the advancements, the south of the Union is burning and burning more and more.
Therefore, the Resolution adopted by this Parliament cannot be just another resolution that merely highlights the great concern we feel for others' misfortunes.
Forest fires occur for various reasons, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

And, regardless of the responsibilities that may exist in certain states or autonomous communities, the fact remains that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act swiftly and to deploy all the resources at its disposal, which are not insignificant, to this end.
Neither the victims, nor the damages suffered, nor the needs for reforestation understand bureaucracy, nor can they comprehend budgetary cycles.

Prioritization and action are necessary. In this case, acting means modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them, and optimally coordinating preventive policies, demanding, once the moment arrives,

In this case, it assigns responsibilities to states that lack them, but assuming that this is not a problem exclusive to southern European states, and that climate change does not only affect some states, it affects all and is a common cause.
Therefore, one of the main tasks that this Parliament has in the near future must be to ensure that the European Union obtains clear commitments at the upcoming Copenhagen Summit.

decisive actions to maximize the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, because, evidently, they are at the root of wildfires, their causes, and these, in turn, are linked to the causes of further climate change.
Therefore, approving this Resolution is now the challenge for this Parliament, without a doubt.
But let the Commission's challenge be met if, indeed, Commissioner, you wish to prevent the South of the Union, which does exist, from continuing to burn.
Mr. President, thank you very much for granting me the floor. I am addressing Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have been following you with great interest and deep respect for a long time, since you were a leader in a country that is very close to us and dearly loved, namely Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that now you have me absolutely astonished.

I am surprised for two reasons, firstly, because you have shown contempt towards the group I belong to, the Non-Attached Members' Group, not deeming us worthy of a single minute of your time to come and share your political proposals with us.
We represent many European citizens, and you have shown contempt for all our voters.
Secondly, due to the fragility of its political project, and the poverty of its political proposals in the document "Political Guidelines for the Next Commission."
some proposals that do not even begin to reflect the positions you have upheld throughout your own term as President of the Commission.
In this regard, I have been surprised that issues such as energy, which have been well addressed throughout your term, now, as you present your proposals to us,

Madam Commissioner, you concluded your remarks by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began by saying that you had already taken all the necessary measures and that the situation was being resolved.
Look, to correct is the mark of wisdom.
And that is a Spanish saying that could be very aptly applied to the case that concerns us today.

The dairy sector has been suffering for months from one of the most severe crises in its history. Despite this, due to the refusal to yield, whether from you, the European Commission, or certain governments, including what appears to be my own, the Spanish government, which denies reversing the decisions of the Health Check of the CAP, the Common Agricultural Policy.
These decisions were made without considering the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that emerged after that commitment was closed.
It seems that the Member States either did not want to or could not see the storm that was brewing at the time.
The reform became outdated in a short time due to the significant shift in the market, a change that demonstrates the sector's complete vulnerability to price volatility.

That major producers such as France and Germany, countries that achieved, in absolute terms, the largest increase in their national production quotas under that agreement, are now the ones calling for a review of the check-up's decisions, gives much cause for thought.

In my understanding, the Member States were mistaken and should have listened more attentively to the voices, mine included, that called for postponing any definitive decision on the future of the sector until 2011.
A shame they didn't listen to us.
You will listen. Do it now.
Mr. President, this Parliament is the Palace of Chimeras, it is the Palace of Dreams.
The Irish people, with their strong vote, give us the encouragement and strength to continue thriving and to build a strong Europe, and above all, a federal Europe.
Only in this way, only in this way, would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs to the fathers of Europe, whose work brought us all here.

Mr. President, having overcome the concern generated by the approval of the Lisbon Treaty, it is time, in my view, to consider how to address nationalist attitudes that so hinder European construction in the future.
My idea is that these obstructions cannot come without cost.
With a clear mind, it is time to consider the possible measures to be taken in the days and years ahead.
This modest representative wishes for a future President of the Council who is a man, or better yet, a woman, convinced of European federalism, capable of steering the...
euro, which is located in the Schengen area and is identified and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
In other words, on behalf of the Commission, I would have nothing more to add, but I already had my speech prepared on behalf of the Socialist Group.

The breakdown of the constitutional order in Honduras ends two decades without coups in Latin America and sets a perverse precedent for other countries, especially the weakest ones, as is now the case with Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and silent in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting President Arias' mediation, in line with the position adopted unanimously by the OAS with the backing of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president, Michelete, has breached the recently reached agreements, mocking the international community and preventing, among other measures, the return of the duly elected president, Mr. Celaya, to office.

Under the current circumstances, the election of a new president in the elections scheduled for November twenty-ninth suffers from a lack of legitimacy from its inception, and its results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would commit a serious error if it were to send a delegation to observe the elections, as this would be interpreted as an endorsement of the coup d'état. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament is renowned as a guardian of freedom, democracy, the rule of law, and respect for human rights.
As Václav Havel stated this morning, there cannot be two weights or two measures.

We are all democrats here and, consequently, freedom fighters. And therefore, whether we speak of Cuba, China, North Korea, or now Honduras, our discourse must be firm against those who suppress liberty.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preference.
There are no right-wing or left-wing coup plotters or dictators, only freedom-killers and oppressors.

Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change, and as a result, a very dangerous precedent will have been set. The doctrine of the "good," temporary, and not-too-cruel coup will have prevailed.

Mr. President, I would like to congratulate the members of the ENVI Committee and its Chair, Mr. Leinen, for the work they have done to enable us to have a Resolution such as the one we have and which we must approve unequivocally.
We cannot be content with talking about having enough with sectoral agreements, because talking about a patchwork agreement is already admitting a part of the failure.
We have decided to adopt this Resolution, which has three noble aspirations.
A more explicit one is to prevent climate change with concrete proposals for emissions reduction and with a commitment to funding, and aiming for a binding agreement, I say, not a patchwork.

and two latent aspirations: one, to start sooner rather than later to work towards a common energy policy, as we once endowed ourselves with a common agricultural policy because it was necessary; and the other, of course, which is also included, is to regain the trust of citizens in politics and politicians, of which we have more than enough in Europe.
In that regard, the success of the Summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
Therefore, I encourage the acting President of the Council to maintain his optimism, to apply pressure and negotiate as much as possible to bring others on board for this success.

I do not know if the leaders of this multipolar world wish to be called into question by history for their inability to reach a binding agreement, but I, as a representative, and I believe all representatives of the people, cannot be called into question by history for failing to secure the binding commitment we have to humanity in Copenhagen to avert climate change.

There is no doubt today about the European Union's commitment to the fight against terrorism, and thanks to the Stockholm Treaty, the Stockholm Program, we will continue to make progress in this area of freedom, justice, and security, which is so necessary.

However, in my view, this struggle has been based on mutual trust among member states. It is high time, with the opportunities provided by the Lisbon Treaty, to harmonize national legislations towards the non-prescription of terrorist offenses, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this happens, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has happened, happens, and may continue to happen, to the detriment of terrorism victims, who see how those who murdered their loved ones are treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore call on this Parliament to promote or adopt the European Charter of Victims' Rights in Terrorism, based on the defense of memory.
Mr. President, I would like, first of all, to congratulate Mrs. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in addressing the international food supply needs.

Now that the European Commission appears to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the community budget, it must be said loud and clear that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food self-sufficiency should be. In past decades, it has been seen that without the CAP, food self-sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture, therefore, cannot be compared to other sectors of the economy that are able to thrive in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to move his business forward, and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
I believe, therefore, that there should be a change of direction in the CAP, but it should not disappear.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to ensure direct aid to farmers, as well as reestablish a policy for managing agricultural markets that provides greater price stability. This would benefit not only farmers, but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to foster balanced relationships among the different actors in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
Furthermore, there is a need for a consumer information policy for Europeans that highlights the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union environmental regulations.
environment, food safety, and animal welfare, because community producers have to compete with productions from third countries, where, for these imports, much lower standards are applied.

And these producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply their own domestic markets due to a genuine issue of profitability, with the backing of WTO negotiations.
According to a United Nations report, in 2009 approximately 270,000 people were victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary for the action of the European Union to be primarily based on the protection of victims, with special attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to attend indifferently to this theater, to this spectacle of sexual exploitation that is unfolding before our eyes.
Therefore, I fully support this Parliament's request that assistance to victims be unconditional, more robust, and with harsher penalties, as Mr Barrott has just told us.
With that said, I would like to ask the President and the Council to use all European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European protection order for victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the Stockholm Programme debates and which has finally been brought to light, will be an effective instrument in the fight against these crimes.

I expect a firm commitment, as we have already seen, from the Spanish Presidency for this order to provide victims with special protection measures that are effective across the entire territory of the European Union.

I hope that those of us with the responsibility to act on the most serious problems in our society provide a real and concrete response to this extremely grave issue of human trafficking, and that we do not merely content ourselves with fine words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr. Zapatero, for a Spaniard such as myself, it is an honor to greet your presence here in your capacity as President of the European Union.
There are high expectations and challenges during this period, and of course, we cannot fail to meet the expectations generated.
that citizens see our renewed institutions as a tool capable of providing solutions to real problems.
But we have included it, as Your Honor knows it is a shared understanding among us.

For the People's Party of Spain, this is a matter of national importance, and we will support your honor in all areas that we believe represent common interests for Europe and are significant for Spain.
It is an ambitious program, and one that, hopefully, will be filled with content.
I would like for people to be able to see, in that album of the Spanish Presidency, since it will surely be colorful and varied, a milestone in each event addressing real issues that affect them.
The crisis strikes economies, and unemployment seems like a fifth horseman of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to acknowledge that twenty percent unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not incapacitate you.
What I believe is that it obligates us all to produce a solution to a problem that we truly need to solve together.
That was a real problem.
Time does not permit me to say much, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain has many challenges ahead. I believe, and I am certain of Spain's capabilities as a nation, that I want to believe and I am sure that you will rise to the occasion for our country.

We cannot disappoint, at this crucial hour for Europe, these expectations. On the other hand, the globalized world, which has been intelligently referenced, gives rise to new power centers, and it is necessary for the European Union to play a more active and coherent role in defense of its values and interests.
Otherwise, we risk becoming irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, Spaniards do not accept that anyone should question our ability to make proposals.
We possess that legitimacy.
What we also need to have is the humility to accept those pieces of advice that Sancho gave to Don Quixote, when he recommended humility to him in the daydream of governing the island of Barataria.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has not ceased to surprise European women with highly innovative and progressive measures.
of course, the formation of a truly egalitarian government and the courageous manner in which she has brought issues of gender equality and respect for others to the national and European agenda.
Mr. President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious program of action, of course, against gender-based violence, which is a social scourge.
The establishment of a European Observatory on Gender-Based Violence is a cutting-edge proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Portuguese socialists, I wish you good luck.
You can count on our solidarity.
solidarity with Zapatero by the women.
Mr. President, on a matter as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to unfold before taking action.
We should anticipate this, but we do not.
And, unfortunately, we are moving forward in response to attacks such as the failed Detroit attack, which today compels us to make decisions that ensure the safety of air transportation.
Deciding on full-body scanners in airports is a responsibility we cannot shirk, ladies and gentlemen.
We cannot keep waiting because terrorists do not wait.
Therefore, the Commission must assure us as soon as possible that the dignity and privacy of individuals will be preserved and that there will be no negative health effects.
With this guaranteed, we must adopt decisions for the entire European Union.

And for those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I will tell them that there is no higher right than the right to live. And for those of us who love freedom above all, we need to live in safety to truly feel free.
Mr. President, I believe that this crisis is an opportunity to move forward with determination and conviction in the creation of a strong Europe.

In that strong Europe, it is likely that the expression "improving coordination" will have to be dispensed with, as it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and strictly speaking refers to paralysis and indecision.
We know that the public finances and debts of European countries will continue to suffer until progress is made towards European financial integration and eurobonds are issued.

In any case, European institutions can already carry out concrete actions. I do not insist on the rhetoric of coordination. And there we have, on the one hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision.
Good evening. I wish to state that I have not come to this Parliament to applaud the newly enacted law in Spain on abortion.

What concerns me is human life, and I am concerned about everything. I am here to defend women whose lives are at risk due to gender-based violence and to offer them a space where they can live freely and safely.

The Resolution of this Parliament of February 2, 2006, recommends that Member States adopt a zero-tolerance attitude towards all forms of violence against women and take the necessary measures to ensure better protection for victims.
The Stockholm Program, adopted in this Chamber, established a space of freedom, justice, and security for all European citizens, and it prioritized the fight against gender-based violence.

In it, my request to the Spanish Presidency was reflected to promote, during its term, a European protection order for victims of gender-based violence, in order to ensure that victims of these crimes have the same level of protection in all member states.

In a borderless Europe, the fight against gender-based violence should likewise know no borders, and member states should strive to harmonize their legislations so that the idea of combating violence against women transcends...

legislative obstacles and, ultimately, we could offer, at least within the European Union, we could protect the lives of women and their children. I therefore call on the Commission and the Council to do everything in their power.

it is necessary and within their power to ensure the success of this European Protection Order for Victims, which is a highly effective tool in the fight against impunity for those who do not respect women's dignity or their right to live freely and safely.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy put an end to the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which once resonated so strongly and inspired hope among the peoples of the world, particularly the most promising segments of international youth.
What characterizes, however, at this moment the dictatorship of the Castro brothers is the cruelty towards political and conscientious prisoners, the cruelty against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco in his death throes, with his mistreatment of political prisoners whom he also considered common criminals, his very same obsessive contempt for the exiled.
Castro ends up like Franco and all enemies of freedom when they entrench themselves in power.
But we must save lives and stand in solidarity with those who fight and suffer.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Madam President, President of the Council, Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with those who seek to restrict our freedoms.
Never again allow a person who fought for their rights and those of all to die in a Cuban prison or anywhere else without our strong and firm voice demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a forty-two-year-old black construction worker, who merely demanded an improvement in prison conditions, died after eighty-six days of a hunger strike and seven years in prison for advocating respect for human rights.
And during those seven years, he was mistreated, humiliated, and degraded by his captors, all while the international community maintained a thick silence.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, such as psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Madam/Mr. President, the Resolution we are presenting today, which we are debating today, and which we will vote on tomorrow, and which I represent on behalf of the Social Democrat Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
once again speaks out in favor of a democratic transition and the strict observance of fundamental human rights.
Let us not delve, for the moment, into a topic that divides us as to whether or not to maintain the common position.
Let us focus on the issue at hand, which is saving lives and human rights.
and let us open a period of calm reflection in which we seek common ground on the issues of future policy towards Cuba.
But this text also has an important added value.
The fact that it is presented by six political groups expresses a new era of broad consensus in this House on the issue of human rights.

that it is never again asserted that European democratic right-wingers bow to so-called orders from Yankee imperialism, but also that it is never again said that social democrats are complacent or accomplices of communist dictatorship.

Simply because both statements are false, and the victims of those who seek to restrict freedom, wherever they may be, should know that we will stand united in the unconditional defense of their cause.

Mr. President, lastly, I would like to thank Mr. Salafranca, who negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Mrs. Weber from the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group, and Mr.

Thank you, Ms. Romeva, on behalf of the Greens Group, to Mr. Kasutnik of the Conservatives and Reformists, and to other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated, but I hope successful effort tomorrow.

Lastly, I would also like to thank the President of the Spanish Government and the President-in-Office of the European Union, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in advancing this Resolution that we are debating today.
"History will absolve me" was the famous plea of a young lawyer that moved his people.
History indeed absolves him of his rebellion against tyranny and subsequently against the American blockade.
But with the same emphasis, this Parliament, which represents the largest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship that...
endured by the people of Cuba, the violation of human rights on the island, the impiety towards political prisoners, the disdain for their exiled nationals.
The judgment of history is clear.
With this Resolution, deputies from all ideologies stand in solidarity with the Cubans who are fighting.
Every possible effort must be made to avoid the brutal repression they endure, even surpassing the paralyzing so-called Common Position.
I pay homage to the poet Raúl Rivero in the last verse of his Havana. Do not impose taxes on affection, emptiness, suffocation, bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are safe.
Calm down, colleagues.
We're leaving now.
This week, International Women's Day was celebrated.
In this Parliament, we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union stating that yes, it is possible to end violence against women.

Today, we are discussing violence in Mexico, and it seems pertinent to acknowledge that Mexican women, both indigenous and non-indigenous, are among the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, ranging from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the army or police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, thus far, the responses of Mexican authorities have been ineffective, and thus, it is accurate to speak of nearly absolute impunity.
Our Resolution calls on the Mexican government to combat feminicides—a harsh but accurate term given that nearly all murders committed against women go unpunished.
An example in the State of Mexico, in the last four years, is that only eleven of the criminals who murdered nearly seven hundred women were convicted.
At the same time, it appears that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible for two indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, to be sentenced to 21 years in prison and even
now spent more than three years in prison for looting Erasolitas during an incident at a market, six men from the Federal Investigative Agency.
research. Hopefully, the judge, who will decide on the appeal in this case within a week, will realize the absurdity and injustice of the situation. But violence against women starts at home.

I hope that Mexican legislators will very soon improve the General Law on women's access to a life free from violence so that it defines the types of violence and the mechanisms that make the rules operational.
Similarly, it would be fitting to establish that domestic violence and marital rape are criminal offenses.
Furthermore, in order for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that in schools this issue becomes a central matter in the education of young people.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do this evening is to thank Mr Escotá for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a true pleasure to work with him and with the other spokespersons of the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated tomorrow in the vote in this European Parliament, and we are proud of a stance like this one, which upholds quality and promotes the development and enhancement of rural areas, not only as...

not merely testimonials of a traditional European culture, but as true generators of wealth and employment, employment which is so desperately needed now in these times of economic crisis and the dramatic employment situation in some Member States.
We also appreciate the stance maintained by this European Parliament, and its position, which the Agriculture Committee has already made clear, is to prioritize quality to the highest degree.
And to that maximum extent, of course, we bet on maintaining that differentiation between designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Of course, we reject the idea of lowering quality standards, and we advocate for attention to be focused on community production, with its value being recognized and enhanced.
I welcome Commissioner Cholo's words.
which, of course, was a pleasure to hear him speak about the bet on the future of the European agricultural sector.
Certainly, we hope that you will heed the voice of this Parliament, which will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

And finally, I would like to say that we hope that it never happens again that the European Commission gets ahead of this Parliament by banning things like, for example, the marketing standards for fruit and vegetables, which have caused so much harm to European free competition.
We seek to rectify market imbalances and also to invest in quality, diversity, food security, and an appropriate level of production.
We also want community productions and the quality of those community agro-food productions to be defended at the World Trade Organization.
And for that, of course, we also rely on the work of Commissioner Cholos, because our producers and European consumers cannot remain defenseless.
Mr. President, the Commissioner has spoken of the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us, therefore, be consistent.
We have lost too many opportunities, too many treaties to introduce Community competence over European airspace.
But if we could not intervene as we should in heaven, we can on the skin of the earth.
for example, by monitoring passengers' rights and also mediating or calling for a truce in the various land transport collective conflicts.
No minimal services, maximum services to all parties.
Many thanks, Madam President. When, from different and distant positions, such as those of Mauro, Gollnisch, or Coleman, one reaches the conclusion that...
the procedure, electoral systems, the election of Members of the European Parliament present problems. That means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

which was a mandate already contained in the Treaties of Rome. That is why the coordinators, and I would like to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to all of them, but especially to Mr Jauregui and Mr Duff, have agreed on an amendment.

2. Tomorrow the vote will take place, and I hope that this House will support it, precisely so that we can resolve this issue, this matter of a uniform electoral procedure for elections to the European Parliament, in the near future.
I believe that by doing so, we would eliminate this type of question.
In his address, Mr. Traskowski spoke of the necessary representativeness of this Chamber, and this is a factor that most speakers, including Vice President Shevkovich, have highlighted.
I agree, and we state this in the report of Article One, that the eighteen should enter as a block, because if they did not, we would lose representativeness.

And to ensure they enter as a bloc, to fulfill that act of political justice that is the Lisbon Agreement, we, Madam/Sir, must be pragmatic, because a transitional and exceptional situation also requires transitional and exceptional situations or solutions.

And that is why I do not hide it. I do not like the possibility of deputies entering this Chamber who have not been elected in the elections of the year two thousand and nine. I state this clearly in paragraph two. But if I have to choose between that and the alternative...

either let in the eighteen or find a pragmatic solution and let in the eighteen, and thus comply with the Lisbon Agreement. I ask this House, and this is why I have presented this report, to opt for that temporary, pragmatic solution, but above all, Madam President, a fair one.
Many thanks to everyone for their collaboration and for the interesting contributions they have made to this work.

As I was unable to do so on March 11th, the International Day of Remembrance of and Tribute to the Victims of Terrorism, I would like to pay them a well-deserved tribute from this Parliament today, recognizing the immense sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to begin work on a Directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the ones forgotten and endure the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their perpetrators.
It is high time that these European institutions recognize the dignity of victims of terrorism and assist them in their right to protection and justice, which should soon be translated into law.

that will honor all those who make it possible, and that the first article be that support for victims of terrorism be recognized as the right to justice, and that no government ever pay a political price.

I appeal to all who can defend the victims never to forget that true peace is born of justice, and it is the only peace that those of us who believe in justice must defend, from Europe and from anywhere in the world.

It has been necessary, Mr. President, for us to stand before the abyss and economic collapse for heads of state and government to understand that the path is not one of more nationalism, but of more Europe.
In this direction, measures adopted such as the decline of the right of veto in the European Council or the seed of a European public treasury are circulating.
Finally, albeit belatedly, we have realized that we are all in the same boat and that it is futile to address individual situations, especially in an improvised manner.

But I wonder whether this attitude is a parenthesis or, on the contrary, the beginning of a genuine European economic government, because what is in excess, dear colleagues, is governance and what is lacking is genuine government if we wish to remain faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

Therefore, from this Parliament, we must promote all those reforms aimed at strengthening Europe and making budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, while setting aside, of course, nostalgic notions of sovereignty.
Colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and this Parliament is the only sure recipe for building a Europe that would otherwise fade away like a fleeting shadow.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, from the INTA Committee, I would like to thank Ms. de Sarnez for the collaboration we have had.
Today more than ever, unity for the Mediterranean, the strengthening of major projects, and institutional development are necessary.
Today, more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to the exit from the crisis, research, climate change, water, new energy models, and sustainable development.

And to achieve this, it is necessary to promote and conclude commercial and economic relations in the region, with short- and long-term measures, a free trade zone, the elimination of tariff barriers, and the opening of the North-South and South-South markets.
The Barcelona summit, the Spanish Presidency, will offer the opportunity for a new commitment, a new situation, a new joint endeavor, democratization, and economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona Summit can position us to lead the Mediterranean.
Madam President, within the transeuropean transport corridors is the railway corridor known as the Mediterranean Corridor.
It is a vital communication link that will connect North Africa with Europe.
For Spain, this axis is vital as it is a priority, since it would connect Algeciras with Europe.
not excluding other priority corridors, would pass through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community, and Catalonia.
And why? Commissioner Reding has stated, citing increased economic activity and a significant concentration of land transport.
This is one of the two conditions.
the possibility of communicating with various ports in the Mediterranean region opened up.
It is necessary to gain economic momentum, to be competitive, as the commissioner also mentioned, because this region produces more than fifty percent of Spain's exports.
Therefore, if we enhance the scope of a strategic railway axis across the Mediterranean, we will increase competitiveness for Spain and competitiveness for Europe.
Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Spanish rotating Presidency on the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the...
common position on Cuba and to establish a new type of relationship between the European Union and Cuba, which would naturally include, as a priority issue, the defense of human rights.
That policy has not been crowned with success, basically due to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship, which began this Presidency precisely in January of [the year in question].
This year, with the expulsion of the representative addressing you, who was attempting to visit the island, with all the visas and full legality, to concern himself with human rights there.
But that policy, that new policy initiated by the Spanish government, will bear its fruits sooner rather than later.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues, this is a regulation of utmost importance for consumers and the agri-food industry, because it is by no means easy to achieve a balanced labeling that includes all essential information, yet is not so exhaustive as to complicate the message.
This is an excellent report, and the rapporteur deserves congratulations.
I agree with her on the major issues concerning nutritional information and the controversial matter of profiles, especially considering that the Commission failed to
commitment to establish said profiles, as well as their conditions of use, before January nineteen, two thousand nine, as prescribed by Regulation nineteen twenty-four two thousand six.

There is an issue that concerns me, and that is the possibility of coexistence with national labeling standards, as it goes against the very objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and the elimination of all possible barriers to the functioning of a genuine single market.
Regarding the indication of the country of origin, current legislation stipulates that this information must be provided when, in the event of omission, it could mislead the consumer.
Additionally, it is foreseen that there will always be a voluntary labeling system.
Going further could complicate matters, potentially incurring economic costs and administrative complexity for companies without providing any clear significant benefit to the consumer.
As for the use of different languages, I must say that the Commission's proposal aligns with the existing Directive, which has functioned well and has not presented any issues.

During these six months of the Spanish Presidency, I would like to distinguish between, on the one hand, the political direction and, on the other, the work of the officials who have been laboring in the engine rooms.
It is the first one that has failed, and this is due to the absence of adequate momentum from the Presidency of the Government, which has been more of a pendulum-like swing.
However, I would like to emphasize the efforts of the officials, their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And it is, Mr. President, that Spain has magnificent professional civil servants and, if there is anything to lament, it is that they are too often marginalized in daily reality.
Having said this, it is necessary to acknowledge that some commendable initiatives have been undertaken in these six months.
Among them, I am pleased to highlight the organ donation and transplantation plan, as well as the approach taken towards patient rights in cross-border healthcare.
The agreements on the new 2020 Strategy, and especially those concerning the European External Action Service, have been left hanging in the air, both still far too fragile.

Lastly, the progress made in the pursuit of improved European economic governance cannot, in any way, be attributed to its Presidency, which has been conspicuously absent on the most pertinent issues.
Farewell, then, to the Spanish Presidency.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I agree with Commissioner Cholos that this report is very necessary and comes at a good time, because the abuses committed by large distributors have been demonstrated, severely disrupting the different links in the food chain.

The Bové report, which at times may go too far in its attempt to be overly interventionist, must be acknowledged from the perspective of a social market economy, as advocated by the European People's Party. I state that it must be acknowledged for addressing the legitimate demands of European producers.

Furthermore, it brings transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always beneficial, and provides many more opportunities and means of defense for the weakest sectors in that chain. It also, of course, supports European consumers in gaining a better understanding of the food chain.

The European food industry might have been given more consideration within this report, perhaps, and that would have been very beneficial. However, this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, which was very necessary.

Measures are also being introduced to bring fairness to these links in the chain, as called for by the Environment Committee. There is also a call to combat abusive and unfair practices by large distributors.
And it is high time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to categorically prohibit them.
It is important, moreover, to adopt measures to prevent unfair practices through private labels that undermine competition and infringe intellectual property law.

For all these reasons, the Bové report should be supported, as should all the colleagues from the different parliamentary committees INCO, ENVI, or Agriculture who have demonstrated their hard work to ensure that this report finally sees the light of day and assists European producers in moving forward.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if, one day, the big fish decides it will no longer eat the small one, we would have to pay the entire generational cost out of our pocket, with our health and well-being as the currency of exchange.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change, and has been for some time in pioneering and conservation measures.

However, as the unmet objectives demonstrate, it appears that there was a lack of will, not only in implementation and coordination—which have also been mentioned here—but also in expansion to go beyond our very limited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be confined to a ghetto-like area, as it sometimes seems to be treated, with only an occasional glance in its direction.
Biodiversity is alive and knows no borders, spanning the entire Earth with a domino effect where if one piece falls, all the others fall as well.

And I draw attention to the need for a more global and community-oriented will, especially regarding the soil, because subsidiarity, as the sole method for soil or forest management, can be one of the new formidable enemies of biodiversity.

That is why I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the possible vote that will be taken, and I ask you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on soils would contribute to the conservation of the entire territory.

Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, first of all, I would like to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Ms. Macaban, not only in terms of content but also in terms of form, as she has done it in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.

The objective of this pharmacovigilance system of the European Union is to enhance the surveillance, transparency, and communication of the safety of medicines after they have been placed on the market, particularly with regard to their risk profiles and the adverse reactions that may occur.

It is important to highlight the establishment of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will evaluate and provide recommendations to the European Medicines Agency on safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.
It is very important to reach a solution for the notification to eudravigilance of suspected adverse reactions, both by the Member States and by the marketing authorization holders of the medicines.

Eudravigilance will be the sole source of information, but simultaneously, the competent authority of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected to have occurred will be notified, and this is of utmost importance.
It is also important to highlight the opportunity available to consumers to report any adverse reactions, and in this regard, the creation and management by the Agency of a dedicated portal.
A European portal on drug safety, which in turn links to the portals of each member state, will help improve citizens' knowledge about the safety of the medicines they consume.

And lastly, we cannot forget that, since pharmacovigilance plays a crucial role in safeguarding public health, the adoption of the Directive and the subsequent implementation of its measures will contribute significantly to ensuring the safe and effective use of medicinal products.
This directive and regulation will contribute significantly to this goal, by improving not only current procedures but also the coordination of actions among the different Member States.

Mr. President, Commissioner, the Directive adopted in two thousand nine was a success because it updates the regulatory framework that has been governing toy safety.
It is a significant step in the right direction as it points us towards the path to follow, but it is not enough.
We must always remain vigilant and attentive to ensure that the toys being marketed do not jeopardize the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.

We must review and improve surveillance mechanisms to identify hazardous toys, whether due to substances considered toxic by the ECMR, fragrances, and other dangerous substances such as HPA compounds.
It is necessary for the guidelines to be clearer regarding the warning about the minimum age and the dangers resulting from improper use.
The recommended age for toys should be based on studies of children's behavior.
We need to be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advancements, backed by robust studies, and be more rigorous in market surveillance and the importation of toys.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation among member states, and to have the joint work of customs authorities to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are preparing to do their Christmas shopping, and we must assure them that the products they purchase meet all safety requirements.
I believe that in this debate we have made it clear that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
Different political groups have shown their support for this Directive, which provides greater protection for victims.
Therefore, I ask myself, what obstacle exists in approving this instrument?
I repeat, what are the fears that something as necessary and straightforward as protecting victims equally across Europe is finally becoming a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will overwhelmingly approve this report, I address the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
overcoming the legal obstacles in our negotiations, and I applaud the Commission's recognition of our work, as we recognize the work it will do in the future.

Let us help everyone, I repeat, whether they are men, women, or children.

Madam President, the European People's Party Group will be voting on this report enthusiastically, and my congratulations first of all to the rapporteurs, the Commission, and the Council for this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, in the 1980s the term democratic deficit.
By this, we meant that in the European Union, decisions were made solely by the Council of Ministers upon proposal by the Commission, and this Parliament was merely consulted.
The battle of this Parliament since the 1980s, through the Maastricht Treaty, the Amsterdam Treaty, the Nice Treaty, the Constitutional Treaty, and the Lisbon Treaty, has been

to bridge that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, and with the involvement of National Parliaments, we have achieved that goal.
And we round off today with this citizen legislative initiative, which was due, in the Convention's work, to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament.

And I would like to mention here the names of Jürgen Mayer, our German Social Democratic colleague, and Alain Lamassure, who were the ones who brought this initiative to the Plenary of the Convention and ensured its adoption.
Therefore, I believe we have come full circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on this initiative, we will have brought to the table, and exposed, the death certificate of the concept of democratic deficit.
It is now our turn, ladies and gentlemen, to act responsibly, and today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the Union's budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us: a responsible Parliament and a co-decision-making Parliament.
I believe this is a good day for Europe, ladies and gentlemen.

Mr. President, in January 2012, four hundred Spanish egg producers, approximately thirty percent of the total in my country, could disappear, resulting in a loss of production of three hundred thousand tons of eggs.

And the European Union could stop producing those eighty million eggs, those two million tons, and we would only achieve having them covered by imports from third countries whose animal welfare standards are far inferior to those of the European Union if we do not act with great intelligence.

This Directive from the year nineteen ninety-nine, which mandates an increase in the space of laying hen cages, requires us to act with intelligence and a pragmatic vision, because if not, we will not comply.

We will only succeed in weakening European production and giving extra opportunities, commercial opportunities, to third countries where the space per bird is infinitely worse than what we currently have in the European Union.

This is a Directive that demands tremendous effort from European producers. Just in Spain, we can estimate that the cost increases to around six hundred million euros, but it is also crucial to remember that it has an economic impact that extends to the ovoproduct industry and the food industry as a whole.

I therefore request the support of your lordships for the amendment of the Popular Group to the second paragraph, where it is requested to seek a solution, at least, for the responsible industrial operations that are proceeding with the transformation of their operations and that by January 2012 will be almost finished.

There is a need to support them in transforming these facilities and to give them time to complete this process, thereby avoiding irreparable harm to farms and preventing a sudden shortage situation in the community market, which would consequently drive up consumer prices.
It is a matter of adhering to the Directive, of giving the egg and ovoproduct industry a chance, while also respecting the right to animal welfare and the consumers' right to a reasonable price.

Mr. President, I believe it is only fair to thank the rapporteurs, especially Ms. Grostet and Ms. Dagmar Ronberend from my own group, for the work they have done to unblock a standard and make it useful, as this work has made it possible to include the right to public health as a legal basis.

and to provide a new direction that allows us to lay the foundations necessary to ensure citizens the safety and quality they choose at each moment, especially since it also clearly regulates the role of states, both those of origin that have to make the payment and those where treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not be satisfied with this alone, but rather that it should be the beginning of a much greater advancement that, as Mrs. Romperen said, makes this Directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all Member States makes it unnecessary for each citizen to travel to each country.

And in this struggle, we must obtain a standard that guarantees the rights of citizens in relation to the care they must receive, benefits, accessibility, and security, more than merely the right they already have to mobility between states.
Equality is what will bring Union, and if not, we will be taking very small steps.
