the issue of organ transplants, which goes against the stance of the Environment Committee due to the Council's persistent insistence on including transplants in this Directive.

I hope that this inclusion does not diminish the effectiveness of the good legislation we approved in this very Plenary, both with the Transplant Directive and the Action Plan, just a short time ago and with almost unanimous support.

And I warn that we will be vigilant to ensure that this inclusion does not undermine the good work done by organizations as successful as the Spanish National Transplant Organization, and certainly not the ambition to save twenty zero lives that we had in both the Transplant Directive and the Action Plan, which, I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I make it clear and state that we will remain vigilant in ensuring compliance with this Directive in that regard.
Mr. President, today is also European Day against Sexual Health.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the data is concerning. The World Health Organization estimates that over three hundred million people are involuntarily infected with a sexually transmitted disease each year.

In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, the increase in the number of unwanted pregnancies among teenagers due to an excessive deficit of education and information among our youth is concerning.

Indeed, as the Commission points out, there are diverse and significant inequalities in access to sexual health services across Europe, varying from country to country and, within each country, depending on the income level of citizens.
To combat all of this, a European strategy is necessary.

Only in five member states are there plans in this regard, but in all of them, it has been possible to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies, infections of sexually transmitted diseases, and also the number of abortions.
A common strategy that prioritizes prevention through education, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and improves accessibility to contraceptive methods.
a cross-cutting and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to ensure every citizen's right to sexual health under the highest conditions of safety and hygiene.
In a time of intense social tensions, it is nothing short of encouraging to witness the significant social dialogue agreement in Spain between the Government, trade unions, and employer associations.
This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where such significant milestones have not been achieved in a long time.

also take into careful consideration the arguments of Cándido Méndez, one of the main protagonists of that Spanish pact, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February 8th.
Candido then insisted on the need to extend coordination to a European scale and on the necessity of having the voice and initiative of trade unions in our Europe.
It must be so.

Mr. President, setting aside the differences in matters of terrorism and immigration, I have observed that the European Union, unfortunately, operates reactively, responding to emergency situations as they arise, akin to treating a severe case.
an attack or a massive landing of immigrants as is currently happening in Lampedusa, where the exodus of Tunisian citizens to the Italian coast could result in a chronicle of a death foretold.

The journey of hope can end in a cursed voyage, and it will weigh on our consciences, on those of all of us who witness these continuous, uncontrolled flows and do not say 'enough' with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we will put our hands to our heads, but the next day we will forget.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, that the common immigration policy will remain a dream as long as European countries do not commit sufficient economic resources to make Frontex effective.
Talking costs nothing, but action is required.
Do you truly believe that Frontex in its current state can guarantee the security of European borders?
I believe not.

And let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt, and other Maghreb countries do not decide en masse to seek a better future in Europe, but rather do so in their own countries, because that is what they have fought for, and we must contribute to helping them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth when speaking of a common European migration policy, now more necessary than ever.

Madam President, it has already been stated that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and should remain the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that, moreover, reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is noteworthy that in OECD countries, the highest levels of income equality among citizens are found in pension systems, or that due to the crisis, private pensions lost twenty percent of their value in 2008 alone and still remain, to this day, far from the required solvency levels.

All this demonstrates that, at a time of inevitable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be approached in a comprehensive manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies on natality or work-life balance.

some equally ambitious policies on access to and retention in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that also guarantee, from a demographic standpoint, the sustainability of our pensions.
Finally, I regret that the text does not set limits on the abuse of the scholarship scheme in companies, as, generally speaking, these are exempt from all kinds of social contributions.

In my opinion, this is essential for an entire new generation of workers who, if they are being asked to contribute more to secure a decent pension, should also be required to suffer less in order to access decent employment.

Mr. President, Commissioner, we are at a crucial moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects but also on the territorial dimension.
Territorial cohesion aims for harmonious development among territories to enable their citizens to make the most of their unique territorial characteristics.
However, to achieve this goal, it is also necessary to make progress in the area of cooperation between the regions of the Union that face the same challenges and issues.

This is the goal pursued by the European Union's Atlantic Strategy, a common perspective to tackle the shared challenges faced by the region's States, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with the 2020 Strategy and the European Union's policies for the period beyond 2020, particularly with regional policy and maritime policy.
However, ladies and gentlemen, above all, it is necessary for this strategy to be based on renewed multi-level governance, founded on closer involvement of public authorities.
regional and local levels, Member States, the European Union, and stakeholders from the private sector and civil society organizations, including interregional organizations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, as we celebrate International Women's Day, remembering those who, a century ago, fought for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage.
We have come a long way in these hundred years, but there is still much to be done, and true equality remains a dream, while discrimination against women is a harsh reality.

I believe that each one of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, whose dignity is violated, and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this International Women's Day, to express my support and hope for all the women who, in the North African Revolution, are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman cannot be worth half of a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere in the world.
Therefore, we are of equal value and deserve the same.
And I will continue fighting to achieve it, and as long as that equality does not exist, International Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although there are many who do not want to see it, it is a reality that there are women who earn half as much as men, that domestic violence predominantly affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all these facts in this Parliament, and I certainly promise to keep working.
Mr. President, I would like to express my agreement with the opinion of the members who have spoken this morning and who insist on respect for the Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest positive vote will depend on the European Council being willing to acknowledge the role of the aforementioned institutions.
because the new mechanism we are discussing should be an important component of the economic governance led by a European Union.
able to ensure coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise, and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

In other words, it must be avoided at all costs that this effort in which we are embarked ends up in the intergovernmental track, which is a dead end or the track of the predominance of a few states, because all of this would frustrate the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of those that reinforce and balance this delicate structure.
There are essential points that need to be improved, so we must send the report back to the Commission.
The parliamentary process for this report does not end here, therefore.
The initial proposal was poor.
This is what consumer associations were telling us at both the national and European levels.
And, in particular, my respect for the work of the Consumers' Union of Asturias and its president, the indefatigable Dacio Alonso.
We have succeeded in rejecting the general principle of maximum harmonization of the former Article Four.

It must be stated clearly that achieving maximum harmonization by establishing the same level of protection in all member states would result in a reduction of consumer protection for many, as certain countries have a stronger tradition and higher standards in safeguarding consumer rights.

I would like to emphasize, in any case, that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, thereby allowing each Member State to increase the number of clauses it considers unacceptable and invalid in consumer contracts.

reverse the burden of proof in individual clauses, so it is the traders who have to demonstrate that the clauses that deviate from the generally established norms have been individually negotiated, and that the contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and comprehensible manner.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonization regarding abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer survey reveals that 79% of traders believe full harmonization in this area will have little or no impact on their overseas operations.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, allow me first of all to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Schwab, and Mrs. Gerhardt on the excellent work they have done.
and a general reflection.
It is not about increasing protectionism, but rather about not curtailing already existing rights in some of the Member States.
Because, if we aim to and strive for the establishment of a genuine internal market for relations between businesses and consumers, we must
establish a balance in parallel between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of business competitiveness.
This balance involves agreeing on a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that enhance consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community standard to result in the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I am pleased that negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to insist that the rights already established so far should not be curtailed.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis could be an energy crisis, and moreover, either we are not doing the necessary homework to prevent it, or we are not acting at the necessary speed to avert it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature is calling on all of us to make a small gesture in the name of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the lights for an hour, and many public administrations will join them.
but it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are far away, or on insecure energy sources.
We must help countries build a new energy model where renewable energies are at the core of the new system.
We must also support the promotion of new consumption patterns, because, without a doubt, renewables and efficiency are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I would like to appeal to all countries in the Union to join this call, this willingness of five of its states, including Spain, to increase CO2 emission reduction targets to thirty percent, because by doing so we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being at the forefront of freedom and rights, is also a leader in its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Madam President, most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, it has been to denounce violence against women, and I am here again to combat it.

I must say that not only am I not tired of it, but I deem it essential to continue speaking publicly about this human rights violation, as there is no cause that can be defended without a platform, and this Parliament is the best one.

speaker that I have at my disposal to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us, legislators, to compel states to punish aggressors, in accordance with the severity of the crime, and also to assist the victims.

When it is estimated that a quarter of European women have suffered gender-based violence at least once in their lives, and that children are equally affected, I believe it is impossible not to call for greater commitment, as recognized by the Commission in its Action Plan.

I believe it is necessary to keep insisting time and again on protecting victims, as we already did in the European Protection Order for Victims, for which I was the rapporteur and which I hope will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has enjoyed broad consensus and support from the outset, demonstrating that, when it comes to tackling domestic violence, which affects all members of the family,
families, children, elderly people, women and men, should not be a reason for political opportunism, as we all take pride in making progress towards solving this social scourge.

The first thing is to not remain silent, and the second is to get to work, since, although we have been talking about gender-based violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

Something we are doing must be wrong, and therefore, it is time to abandon demagoguery and move from words to actions, providing the necessary additional aid and response so that women can live with dignity and security.
safety, that all victims know that I will always be here to continue to lend them my voice until together we manage to defeat this.
a terrible enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough already, and I ask all of you to say it with me too.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I agree with you that we must listen to citizens and regain trust in the European project.
Therefore, today could be a great day for Europe and European social construction.

Because with the approval of these reports, we not only move forward towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we also thereby respond to the demands of citizens who call for progress towards more Europe and the strengthening of social rights.
Europe must respond to new global challenges and transform the European economy into a highly competitive social market economy, creating sustainable growth with more and better jobs.

But this objective must be based on the inclusion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market, placing citizens at the center of our attention and priority, and strengthening their social rights.
Lastly, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, also to our public health.

a disease against which we were fighting through the use of activated vaccines, which involves the creation of restricted zones for animal movement, because the use of these vaccines can lead to unwanted virus circulation in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of vaccination was limited to those areas where infected animals had previously been found, creating a double disadvantage for livestock farmers: on the one hand, the disease, and on the other, the restrictions.

But all these problems seem to be preventable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to avoiding the disruptions that can be caused in the domestic livestock market, allows for the development of new and broader strategies, which is truly important, for prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all these reasons, it is of vital importance for this sector that we amend the Directive to allow its use, and moreover, that we do so as soon as possible.

Ladies and Gentlemen, compliance with what our Treaties establish, especially regarding correspondence tables, cannot be an excuse for this regulation not to enter into force before the summer, because with its delay we would only be harming livestock farmers.

Mr. President, firstly, I would like to thank the Petitions Committee for the work it has carried out following the complaint lodged by FEPEX, the Spanish Organization of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters, based on the report published in two thousand and seven by OLAF, the Union's Anti-Fraud Agency.

I believe the conclusions of that report are crystal clear and more than justify the European Commission's decision to take action a long time ago to clarify the functioning of the entry price system, at the very least for the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to address potential loopholes that may arise from the Entry Price Regulation in force, but it has also negotiated a new Agricultural Agreement with Morocco without first resolving the flaws in the current import regime.

Ladies and Gentlemen, it is high time the European Commission took its responsibilities seriously and began investigating where frauds are taking place, eventually requesting the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I believe that under no circumstances should a new agreement with Morocco be ratified without first resolving the details we have outlined.

Our goal is not to halt the signing of international agreements, but rather to ensure that such agreements do not severely harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in those agreements are respected.

As regards the new Agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector merely requests guarantees that the effective implementation of the agreed measures will be carried out, and this is only possible through a reform of the entry price regime currently in force.
Until we have a new entry price system, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will not be able to ratify that agreement which the Commission has already closed.

Moreover, if such monitoring is the responsibility of the Member States, it would require a significant financial effort on their part. However, it is also true that we have long been advocating for a European customs border system, similar to that of the United States, to ensure effective control.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, discussing this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because it has involved these measures that require the green light from the World Trade Organization, and the Commission's preliminary proposal sent to Parliament differs from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe it is necessary to assist Pakistan. We understand that exceptional trade preferences can be granted, provided they take into account the sensitivities of the region.
the European industry and, in a very special way, the textile sector, which in communities such as the Valencian Community in Spain are severely suffering the consequences of the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to ascertain that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade are likely unable to be addressed with the urgency these acts require, so we must learn from this for the future.

Assisting Pakistan, yes, but not with the Commission's original proposal, as it does not take into account the effects of the European industry regarding the application deadlines for sensitive products.
even delay the implementation of these measures due to their lack of alignment with the text pending approval by the WTO, we would be past the deadline.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and believe we will have to vote no.
Many thanks, Mr. President. I would like to begin my remarks by congratulating all those who have made it possible to reach an agreement.
This is an agreement that we all should applaud, as it impacts the daily lives of all citizens. However, with the constructive spirit that defines me, I would like to make a few clarifications.
Firstly, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant, but above all, clear and consistent information.
for consumers regarding the components of textile products. Comprehensive information will be of no use if citizens are then unable to decipher it.
We have achieved a positive, necessary but not sufficient step; we should go further and protect those citizens who could become more vulnerable.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to establish a European sizing labeling system based on body measurements, because the first thing we encounter when purchasing a garment is the size.
Therefore, we should be much more ambitious and strive for size harmonization.
Mr. President, three notes on the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and have a great affection for that country, but it is evident that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and imprudence.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European response, we notice that the actions carried out by the Food Safety Authority and the Commission have been weak, lackluster, and imprecise; they have failed to coordinate or provide effective leadership.
Thirdly, those affected have the right to prompt economic compensation.
But, for the time being, I propose to this Parliament that we organize in Brussels or here in Strasbourg a major exhibition of European gastronomy based precisely on the cucumber.
One must reclaim the lost honor, an expression dear to the German writer Heinrich Bell; one must reclaim the lost honor of cucumber producers.
Europe is the appropriate setting for this.
Mr. President, firstly, I am compelled to express my sincere regret for the twenty-three victims who have already perished, twenty-two in Germany and one in Sweden.
And this crisis must be acknowledged as the most compelling evidence that the European Union needs to significantly improve its food alert system and internal coordination.
The involved member states have shown slowness, ineffectiveness, and inaction. At this point, even after twenty-three deaths, we still do not know the source of the problem.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during crises such as the current one, resulting in cases of economic ruin and the destruction of jobs that were previously considered unnecessary.

of instability, unemployment, defenselessness, and, of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population. Because while you, from the Commission, echoed irresponsible statements by regional authorities,

German consumers were very misinformed and rather irresponsible, naming specific Spanish farms, while meanwhile the population remained unknowingly exposed to the bacteria, believing they were avoiding it. Citizens were more exposed than ever to consuming something that could harm them.

The European Commission should today, at the Agriculture Council meeting in Luxembourg at 2 p.m., propose to ministers that part of the two hundred million euros available as unused remnants of the Common Agricultural Policy be utilized.
those two hundred million euros to repair the damage caused as much as possible.

To achieve this, it is necessary to find a legal loophole that allows it, a legal loophole that has been found on other occasions, such as with mad cow disease or dioxins, and which should be found now.
Therefore, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, today in Luxembourg you must rise to the occasion and assume your responsibility.

German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations made, should support this economic solution, without a doubt, from the outset, and also fund, with their own resources, their communication campaigns to restore consumer confidence in horticultural productions.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring the dead back to life, and hopefully, what is being done will prevent more deaths and stop the chain of sick people who are suffering without having done anything to deserve it.

We do not know the causes for certain, but we do know some things that we must call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city-state on another continent.

The arrogance displayed by Mrs. Merkel and her Health Minister in addressing other states with unusual frequency, had they translated it into diligence and effectiveness in coordination, some of the things that have happened would not have occurred.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences for a state that has been the Spanish state and for its most important sector, agriculture, driving thousands of people and small businesses to family ruin and discrediting the economy for a long time.
I request that you go to the Council and demand full compensation for those affected, as we cannot ask for the lives of the deceased.
and that the control systems be reviewed.
and that Mrs. Merkel be held accountable.
and that he be asked for less arrogance and more diligence.
and hold it responsible for the damage it has caused.
You cannot ignore that Hamburg is in your state.
You cannot ignore your responsibilities.
You cannot shelter under a decentralized and federal state to cause the harm you have inflicted.

A little more humility, a little better management, and a little less conservatism would have gone a long way in preventing this crisis from spiraling out of control, and Spain and other southern farmers would not have had to endure its painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems, and demand accountability, because in Spain, we are demanding it, Commissioner, from you, the Council, and the German state.
Mr. President, we are facing a public health issue, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has stated, and in response, they have sought to assign blame, if not identify the cause.

The system has failed. We have twenty-two dead, six hundred affected, and we do not know the cause three weeks later. And, appealing to a precaution principle without a scientific basis—I repeat, without a scientific basis—Spain is being blamed.
Ladies and gentlemen, the Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
contaminated, were not contaminated. I repeat this because some contrary versions have been heard around here.
But to show you the importance of what these words have stirred up, three hundred jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree, Commissioner, you do not know borders. We demand responsibility for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany has a risk problem at this moment, it has a higher number of affected individuals, but Spain is not at fault.
We demand reparations.
What is important and what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as European consumers feel today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

And it is my responsibility to report to the German authorities that they unjustly and precipitously accused Spanish cucumbers, and specifically the cooperatives in Málaga and Almería, which were model farms and will not recover from these accusations.
Thousands of jobless families wonder why, why they need an answer and, above all, what their future will be, not just in Andalusia, but across the entire agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will find a swift solution, I urge the Commission that, when it speaks with the Council today, it demands immediate economic and moral measures for all producers in Andalusia and across Europe who are looking to us with indignation but with hope.
Instead of prioritizing European research and collaboration, German authorities have slandered and harmed cucumber producers and others.
And still, no one in Germany has resigned or offered reparations commensurate with the harm caused.
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
It is intolerable how Mrs. Merkel treats the southern countries in matters of agriculture and finances as well.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
None of that, it lacks credibility. Moral.
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and some other countries share our reluctance to readily accept the so-called eurovignette.

Coincidence is the critique that arises from our status as peripheral countries. Ultimately, we will be the ones to pay this unique tax that will be collected by the central European Union states with geographical centrality.
The rationale behind the eurovignette scheme is fraught with significant contradictions, and the supporting argument grows weaker by the day.

Although it is accepted as a starting point that the rationality of internalizing external costs should be considered, in the end, it does not hold up to penalize only high-tonnage vehicles to alleviate congestion, while leaving passenger cars exempt, on the same terms as the old slogan "the polluter pays" is applied with obvious discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the eurovignette, which was envisioned as a source of infrastructure funding, in the end, only fifteen percent will be allocated to the financing of trans-European networks, and not mandatorily.

but rather as a simple recommendation, so that the incumbent Minister of Finance will allocate the funds collected to the purpose that they deem most suitable for the interests of their country within the broad category of infrastructure.
The final result will be nothing less than another blow to road freight transport, which, as of now, is the only mode enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much harsher in the context of an economic crisis.

In that regard, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot afford experiments that could further deteriorate the precarious situation of the European economy by imposing new additional costs.

The food crisis, which has been recklessly attributed to Spanish products, has resulted in unfair penalties and significant losses for those already penalized by the eurovignette (road charging scheme) — freight transporters and high-quality crop farmers.
Those are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, why the Spanish Delegation of the European People's Party will vote against this draft directive.

You will all understand, dear colleagues, that in assuming the presidency of this session, I wish to express my deep pain and consternation at the passing of Jorge Semprun, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of eighty-seven.

At Jorge's Emprun, we honor him who was a prisoner in the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the forces of Nazism in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the highly renowned committed writer, a particular collaborator of our program "The European Book of the Year," and we also celebrate the convinced pro-European politician.

I mourn his death, likewise as his colleague and friend, and I will ask President Buzek to convey to his family and the Government of Spain a message of sincere condolences and solidarity that I am sure we all share here.
creation of an economic governance space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to the European construction.
We cannot keep turning a blind eye.
It is incoherent to have a single currency while simultaneously lacking the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency requires.
In concrete terms, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, an outright no to competition between national debt issuances, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, and
harmonization of tax policies that ensure citizen equality, combat tax fraud, and help shape a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas, I will be told, are elementary.
But they must be repeated and repeated because no one listens to them.
And precisely because they do not listen, those dark times of which the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke are upon us.

Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing underscores the necessity of regional policy as the best instrument to reduce development disparities between regions and states.
At the same time, we can recover the positive image of Europe that citizens have lately only associated with harsh austerity measures and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of the solidarity of the European project and social justice, should take into account the following priorities:

Firstly, strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy.

Secondly, consider the needs and characteristics...

geographical characteristics of regions, especially the most disadvantaged ones. Third, uphold the principle of gradualism in fund allocation to ensure regions do not deviate from the convergence objective, preventing abrupt changes in aid receipt. Fourth, promote a system
equitable.
Lastly, ladies and gentlemen, the authorities are implementing strict budget adjustment policies.
Therefore, the support of the Union is necessary.
I hope the Council takes careful note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I call upon the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastián as European Capital of Culture, as I believe it was selected based on a political criterion, which constitutes discrimination against the other candidate cities.

The President of the Court stated that she was chosen to support the peace process and, as far as I know, there exists in Spain a terrorist organization called ETA which, to this day, has not laid down its arms and which, two months ago, managed to have its political wing Bildu govern, among other municipalities, the one of San Sebastián.
I do not believe that from Europe we should give such a powerful voice to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will make propaganda to distribute blame among victims and killers.
killers, where is the right to freedom and dignity?
Of course, not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues, such as Mayor Oreja, Iturgaiz, Salva, or myself, must be escorted.
I believe in the culture of life, not in the "throw the baby out with the bathwater" culture.
Ladies and Gentlemen, can there be true culture without freedom?
No and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastián becomes a free city for all, it should re-submit its candidacy, and in the meantime, they should learn the culture of respecting those who think differently.
Because perhaps tomorrow they will deserve it, but today, with Batasuna and its heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.
Mr. President, first of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their fruitful collaboration in drafting this text.
And the same applies to the other fellow members of the committee from this Parliament.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was established. There is no better way to commemorate this event than by discussing Europe's energy infrastructures today.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its policy for a Common European Internal Market, promoting renewable energies as a means or tool to combat climate change, ensuring supply security, and diversifying its sources.
The Lisbon Treaty devotes a title to energy, the twenty-first, where these commitments I have just mentioned are formulated, and also the promotion of the interconnection of energy networks.
The objective of the report we have prepared is aimed at correcting energy infrastructures that, according to the European Commission, have become outdated and poorly interconnected.

Thus, for example, we are witnessing a spectacular increase in electricity generation from wind power in the North Sea and the Baltic, along with the immense potential for renewable energy in Southern Europe.
Europe and North Africa, with the challenges stemming from large-scale electricity storage, the recharging needs of electric vehicles, among many other urgent issues.
All of this is impossible to address today without devising new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.

In the coming years, therefore, the focus will be on progressing in the identification of necessary infrastructures, by establishing criteria that allow for the selection of projects of European interest.

b, by eliminating energy islands
c, ensuring the implementation of these projects within reasonable deadlines and finding solutions to the contentious issue of
authorization procedures and licensing in the Member States, ensuring funding that attracts and drives private investment, without prejudice to any necessary public support.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central components in the new design incorporated into the report, because we have
believing that by reducing energy demand, dependence on imports can be decreased, with the resulting impact on infrastructure needs.
A central concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licenses and authorizations intended to permit the execution of necessary works.
currently become eternalized.
and they are prolonged due to the opposition of the populations to see towers or other types of installations grow in their vicinity.

To resolve this conflict, early information to citizens and the establishment of a warning system have been proposed, to be implemented in the event that a state's authorities fail to respond to a request within a reasonable timeframe.

My brother Alberto Jiménez Becerril, assassinated by ETA in Seville alongside his wife, was not returning from war; he was heading home to his three children who would never see him again.

Thanks to European aid, food banks have carried out remarkable social work, which should not be paralyzed by the selfishness of some governments.
That work has benefited thirteen million people, and thanks to it, with minimal effort, we have managed to make the common agricultural policy a little more significant.

The regulation we are debating today is not perfect. It cannot, on its own, resolve the problems of a sector facing structural issues, and also, given the economic context we are experiencing, cyclical problems.
But this Regulation, while not perfect, is a decisive step forward in the right direction.

Because if in recent times we have all realized that there is no such thing as a perfect market, it was highly necessary to incorporate into this scenario, where we are also dealing with people's food security, all the regulatory elements and protection measures we could for our producers.

It was highly necessary for us to allow the enforcement of contracts with a minimum term and a maximum volume, at least as a defensive tool, because, of course, our producers do not approach distribution, intermediaries, or collectors with the same negotiating strength.
many things remain to be done.
We will need to improve safety nets and make them more agile and effective.
We must strive to further integrate the sector in the value chain, ensure there is no quota distribution, especially in certain areas, and promote quality policies.

But, without a doubt, with our positive vote and with all that remains to be done, today many farmers will be able to see this Parliament as one that has defended their labor rights, the most fundamental of all, which is the right to live with dignity from the income of their labor.
B. has aptly pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this Agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which increases quotas for certain fruit and vegetable products when the figures of the current agreement are not respected, makes absolutely no sense.

It is worth recalling that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters denounced to the Committee on Petitions, precisely of this Parliament, the massive entry of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price lower than that established in the Agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described place the European farmer in a position of competitive disadvantage.
It should be added that our farmers must adhere to rigorous environmental and social quality standards that our Moroccan partners do not always respect.
To conclude, I will address the issue of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory, and the exploitation of its resources should directly benefit the local population.
Moreover, it constitutes an area over which the UN does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
From the European Union, it is necessary to ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, one that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union regarding quotas and prices. I support an agreement that combats dumping, does not exploit Moroccan farmers, and above all, uplifts our European farmers.
This is not, of course, the agreement.

Last year, the European Parliament's Petitions Committee requested that the European Commission proceed with a modification of the entry price regime for fruits and vegetables in the Union, a regime that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of productions from third countries, as stated by the Union's own Anti-Fraud Agency, OLAF.
mainly they are Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request has been incorporated into a declaration signed last year by the governments of Spain, France, and Italy.
This, this fraud, is resolved by amending the Implementing Regulations for the Common Organization of Agricultural Markets, because aligning the Customs Code does not fix the problem, Commissioner.

For several years now, I have been advocating within the Popular Party the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union equips itself with the necessary instruments to guarantee compliance with the Agreement in force.
The European Commission argues that it is the member states that must ensure the control of imports.

However, what the Commission does not mention is that the entry price regime is in force, and the one in effect prevents national customs authorities from accurately tracing the prices declared by importers to verify that there are no irregularities.

Modify the implementing regulations for the CMO (Common Market Organization) for agricultural products, and we will have resolved part of the problem, because otherwise, the legal loophole in European regulations prevents national authorities from doing their job properly.
No writings. Once again, dear colleagues, the debate about a summit.
Many have been celebrated, all announced with great fanfare, attempting to create an anticipation that diminishes each day.
are ceasing to be credible because they do not contribute to resolving the crisis.
Summits where the same agreements are reiterated time and again.

It should be understood that unless progress is made towards political union and strengthening this Parliament and the executive power of the European Commission, summits will be repeated, but the economic crisis will worsen.
In a telegraphic manner, two ideas: firstly, the need to insist that responsible solidarity and the fulfillment of duties are the
materials with which Europe is built. Secondly, to immediately authorize the use of structural funds that are pending disbursement.
These amounts can comfortably allow for tackling the unemployment figures among young European citizens.

Madam President, from the European Parliament, I wish to pay tribute today to all women who, despite the significant progress made since March 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and better working conditions, I believe that gender equality is still a long way off.
Today, women can work without having to ask anyone's permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
We must also remember the women in rural areas whose labor is overlooked.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

Just this year, there has been an excessive number of women murdered, not counting the serious threats from those who believe they have the right to inflict physical or psychological violence upon them.
It is high time to say enough and to state it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and to the Victims' Directive presented by the Commission, which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
We also have to say, and I would like to remind you, that motherhood continues to be an obstacle to women's progression, and I believe this is a trend that should be changed.
I want to send a message of hope and, together with many women, with the support of an increasing number of men, we must forge ahead on the path towards equal opportunities, rights, and obligations.
We have come a long way, but there is much to be done.
I must admit that I do not fully and deeply believe in quotas, but I have to tell you that something needs to be done, and I agree with that.

many of my colleagues and, of course, with Ms. Reding, in opening this debate and moving forward on this path so that women can reclaim the place they deserve. You can count on my support in this endeavor.

Mr. President, in a context of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting public health, and in which, as is the case in the community where I live, research centers such as the Prince Felipe specialized in diabetes are left without funding, this Resolution is more timely than ever and is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes, and we need a Council recommendation that tells states they must increase research, including with stem cells, that they must coordinate their results to optimize them, and that they must establish programs for healthy eating and lifestyle habits.

In short, we must prioritize the health of individuals and, in this case, investigate, coordinate, and develop national programs led by the Commission, while demanding results on diabetes. This will ensure the quality of life for Europeans and safeguard their well-being.

If we allocate more funds to this, some people will take a little longer to receive their payments, but undoubtedly those who are currently facing difficulties will have a better quality of life. As States, as the Council, and as the Commission, we will be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to ensure the health of our citizens.
Mr. President, of the many issues this debate raises, I would like to highlight the one concerning the emissions rights market, a market that was born with flaws, certainly,
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have led to a drastic reduction in the price of carbon, meaning it is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is urgent, therefore, to reform the design of a policy on this market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, the entire green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, there is an incentive to increase emissions. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques and, what is worse,
the funding of important projects, such as, for example, those related to energy efficiency or carbon capture plants, will be put at risk.
This is the risk.
It is incumbent upon us, the Commission, and Parliament to conjure it.
Mr. President, few refugees are permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has only just begun this experience.
The cases, however, are of urgent need.
The members of parliament have verified this on the ground during their visit to the Iraqi camps of Palestinian origin in Syria, as well as the news that quickly reached us from Tunisia.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between the Parliament and the Council.
Our speaker, the intrepid Ruiz Tavares. There are many good parliamentarians, but few with as much tenacity as Ruiz.
Tavares has advocated for the European Parliament to retain the new powers acquired following the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the ongoing work carried out by UNHCR, without which success would not have been possible either.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so desperately needed.
And finally, many thanks, Commissioner, and I hope that we can also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of advancing the asylum package in the coming month.

The European social model, of which we are so proud, is not founded solely on our pension, education, or healthcare systems, but also on a way of understanding the balances between employers and employees within companies.

The labor reform approved by the Spanish Government without dialogue or consensus breaks with this social model and distances us from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, both in terms of job creation and the quality of employment.
A labor reform by itself does not create employment; economic growth does.
What labor law does do is define the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them, and the conditions under which they leave them.

And with this reform, where eighty percent of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be subject to collective bargaining agreements, and where they can be dismissed due to a decrease in company income.
employers may unilaterally change their schedules, it is clear that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform, which attacks the European social model and prioritizes the competitiveness of the Spanish economy solely in relation to labor conditions, deserves a general strike like the one called for tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr. President, Mr. Barroso, let it be known that the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party deems it correct and supports the two packages you have presented today, both the labor package and the solidarity aid to Greece, which is closely tied to the coherence of your approach.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times, and events each day remind us that the crisis is far from being resolved.
The focus of attention has inevitably shifted back to Spain.
Alarm bells have been unjustifiably set off in the markets, fueled in part by statements that, in my view, Mr. President, were ill-timed.
Some within the context of important elections, where one contender and another cite my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Of course, we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, some, in order to divert attention from their own problems, also concern themselves with us with little political finesse.
Today here too, some have not been subtle, as the Italians would say, and there has been a lack of political tact.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the situation of the markets does not reflect the strength of Spain.
We are a solvent country with full capacity to honor its debts.
Spanish debt remains below the European Union average, and the Spanish government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed upon with the European Union.
Never, gentlemen of Bogota, has Mr. Rajoy stated that he cannot meet the objectives set by the European Union.
has said the exact opposite, that he is willing to fulfill each and every one of those objectives, and he reiterates this every day.

The Government of Spain, in the few months it has been at the helm of the Executive, has adopted and will continue to adopt very ambitious measures to ensure fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for an improvement in competitiveness, job creation, and growth.
The IMF's forecasts, it should be noted, the IMF itself admitted yesterday, are prior to the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish government at present.

Other measures we have adopted in the general state budgets for two thousand twelve, which in our judgment will ensure this year that the deficit target is met, the Organic Law on Budgetary Stability this month will.

It will present a reform in education and healthcare that will amount to a zero million euro adjustment. The reform of the financial sector will also undoubtedly contribute to financial institutions having to allocate more than fifty million euros.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Union and the Commission, and what we are asking for is responsibility from all.

It is necessary for all of us to be saved together, and Spain with all, without any doubt whatsoever, and criticisms from one side or the other contribute nothing. Either all the countries are capable of coming together and contributing to growth and the new path, or, if not, it will be difficult, naturally, for us to move forward on the terms proposed by the Commission.
Mr. Romeva, do you wish to make Mr. Rajoy, the President of the Government, the protagonist?
That seems fine to me, I wouldn't have any objections.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the inheritance received by the Spanish socialist, communist, and green left, which has left the worst inheritance ever left by any government, when they received the best inheritance ever held by any government.
Mr. President, this morning I read in a major German newspaper the news that Spain and Argentina have a conflict related to an oil company.
This is precisely the wrong way to approach the matter.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina, and moreover, with that great European value which is legal certainty and its respect in international commercial relations.
European institutions have excellent legal experts who can find the appropriate instruments in original or derived EU law to neutralize the arbitrariness of Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of Public Law and I offer to collaborate with them.
The credibility of the European Union before its citizens is currently at stake.

Mr. President, from the Agriculture Committee, we share the ultimate goal of this Directive, which is to attempt to shape the composition of our energy mix through fiscal measures. However, we are facing a very complex debate.

filled with challenges in economic, social, and environmental aspects, it is crucial to maintain those balances that allow us to advance further in environmental matters, yes, but also to avoid economic harm and not exacerbate the social crises we are already facing.
It is the case of agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs are increasingly becoming a very significant portion of the fixed costs of our agricultural operations, at a time when, moreover, we are engaged in a debate that combines crises in raw materials markets with a perspective of aids and increasing health and environmental requirements, all of which erode their profitability margins.
That is why we have fundamentally requested two things.

The first is the maintenance of zero-rate deductions in the energy component, now linked to the formulation and implementation of energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the incorporation of...
agriculture among the sectors deemed at risk of carbon leakage, thereby also gaining access to the deductions allowed in the CO2 emissions trading scheme.
In other words, a more environmentally demanding policy, but one that maintains those balances that make our rural environment viable at a time of changes and uncertainties.
We are living through a major controversy that inevitably revolves around the concepts of austerity and growth.
If one hears the noise that is being generated, it would seem that the idea of growth is a bright invention of these times.
nothing could be further from the truth.
In Europe, the pact known as the Stability and Growth Pact has been in force since nineteen ninety-seven.

Therefore, a large part of the policies implemented by European institutions, such as regional cohesion and research policies, are growth-oriented policies that aim to achieve the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and I address the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the greatest chance of being heard, there is no complex on our part when engaging in this debate, which we can approach with our heads held high.
In my opinion, this is a minority view among the unregistered.
Madam President, allow me, first of all, to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs, for their assistance with this report, which has significantly strengthened its content.

We all know that it is the twentieth anniversary of the launch of the single market, which should be the driving force behind economic activity and growth in Europe, key to overcoming the crisis and achieving the goals of Europe 2020.
In these twenty years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development, within a broad framework of consumer protection, growth, and rights that foster dynamism.
and trust, transparency, a basic principle of democracy and good governance, as Commissioner Barnier referred to this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework concerning the protection and training of consumers, and particularly vulnerable consumers.
We are aware that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it challenging to adopt a comprehensive legislative instrument.
This compels us to address the issue of vulnerability through a cross-cutting analysis that takes into account the diverse needs, capabilities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
As an ambitious proposal, it is not sufficient to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive, or the options available to them, or their lack of awareness of existing complaint and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

It is for all these reasons that, in order to address the shortcomings, that is, the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to strengthen vulnerable consumers and for both the Commission and the Member States to introduce specific measures in their legislations to ensure adequate protection.

which goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where the level has proven to be higher and where they record the largest number of consumer complaints: the financial sector, whose complexity means that, potentially, any consumer can become vulnerable.

For this reason, the financial services industry is urged to intensify its efforts to provide understandable, truthful information, with an abundance of clear explanations and using direct language regarding the nature of the products and services it offers. The food industry, in relation to advertising,

from foods with high fat, salt, and sugar content, and to children and young people, who are the most sensitive to the advertising of these foods, the transport sector, which often still faces difficulties when vulnerable people travel, and the energy and telecommunications sector

where the lack of transparency creates, in some cases, an additional difficulty for consumers, for example, in the energy sector when determining the tariff that best suits their needs, in access to justice, where consumers may encounter difficulties in accessing the mechanisms.
resistant.
Therefore, the Commission and the Member States are called upon, and allow me to draw the attention of the Spanish Minister of Justice, Mr Gallardón, to ensure that rights are not rolled back.
and, going against the grain of these challenging times, harness intelligence and good governance in favor of alternative dispute resolution in consumer matters.

In conclusion, it is important to acknowledge that any one of us can become vulnerable consumers. Many thanks, and I would like to express my gratitude to all the members of Parliament for their support in strengthening this report.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the truth is that I am feeling a sense of despair, almost frustration, which I must share with someone.
will allow me to do it this afternoon with you.

This is the third or fourth debate we have had in this Chamber in recent times on the situation of youth unemployment across Europe, and debate after debate, while youth unemployment rates are skyrocketing in some Member States, we are already nearing the point of crisis.

fifty percent of the working population, while many of them are already running out of any kind of social or unemployment coverage. While all this is happening, while we move from a situation that evolves from concerning to critical,

unsustainable and from the unsustainable to the dramatic. The Commission appears, once again, before this Parliament, in this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, and not the true government of the Union, which is what it is and, moreover, what we need.

Commissioner, governing means setting priorities, setting priorities, taking the initiative, moreover, with the aim of achieving some purpose, some objective, and moreover, the Commission is not doing this.

Governing is not merely about restructuring funds, nor is it about announcing such actions to merely appease public opinion. Instead, it is about implementing an ambitious, long-lasting, and swift strategy to eradicate youth unemployment.

Governing is not resigning oneself to a youth unemployment rate above twenty percent and being satisfied with a four million euro pilot project, which is ridiculous given the situation, given the magnitude of the problem we face.

Governing is not yielding to the pressures of the College of Commissioners or other Member States of the Council who strive to convince us that we can only emerge from this financial crisis, this new wave of recession, by giving up wages, labor rights, or severance pay, that our only future as a generation is one of precariousness.

Because if this were true, moreover, Mr. Commissioner, that we only gain competitiveness precariously and that only by being more precarious will we achieve greater competitiveness, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country, which it is not.
Sweden, Finland, and Denmark are such countries, characterized by an exemplary model of relations and also by a model of labor rights and guarantees.
Mr. President, employment is much more than a citizen's right; it is an instrument of connection to the system, a tool for social integration.

Therefore, the higher the unemployment rate, the greater the political disaffection. That is why, Commissioner, I cannot accept your discussions on matters of competence as a way of doing nothing about youth unemployment.

Because, moreover, Commissioner, when you have had to interpret the Treaties loosely to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, you have done so, and when the Treaties have had to be amended to comply with or satisfy the austerity delusions of a particular Member State, we have also done that.
Therefore, what is it that I want to tell you?
There you have it, for example, the guarantee of youth employment does not need to be explained.

Fight to increase the budget, use the European Social Fund as a tool if necessary, design a co-financed and solidarity-based implementation mechanism that most helps those with the highest unemployment rates, push for further changes to this policy of social asphyxiation towards countries that are worst off, and remember that behind every figure there is a person who is suffering.
So, you will think as I do that the least important thing is not whose competition it is, because for the collective of citizens, especially...
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the INTA Committee for its work, the rapporteurs, and the shadow rapporteurs.

In general terms, we are faced with a good SGP regulation, which is necessary, specifically, in certain actions, for controlling the import rules for textile products that could harm European Union production.
However, we are concerned about the exclusion, since 2014, of certain countries from the GSP that are classified as upper-middle-income, countries such as those in Latin America.
Because, what happens with these middle-income countries that have poorly diversified exports?
diversified. Why not introduce a diversification criterion to exports?
Because in this way, two speeds could emerge, benefiting countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador, distinguishing themselves from potentially developed countries such as China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe we should support a transition period, and amendments will be tabled with this transition period to adapt to this situation in these countries and provide the possibility of opening negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they can benefit from it.

Mr. President, I already supported Mrs. Nadelcheva's report when I was able to accompany her on the mission to the Congo along with other parliamentarians, and indeed, I verified that I have seen few peoples with a greater manifest willingness to practice democracy and participate in it.
But a people, in order to believe in democracy, need to also believe in their State and their Government, and that will not be possible with electoral support or external backing alone.
They also need a demand for fighting corruption and breaking the indecent paradox of living in misery in one of the richest countries in the world in terms of resources.

It must be stated and denounced that a portion of the violence they experience is imported or, at the very least, encouraged by those unscrupulous multinationals that, from Europe or other continents or states, are willing to engage in corruption, regardless of fueling conflicts over these resources to gain the favor of those who govern certain territories.

Therefore, Ms. Aston, even though it may not be within your direct remit, I would argue that imposing stricter traceability and transparency requirements on European multinationals and other companies from other continents operating in the region would be as beneficial for the development of the local population as the electoral and technical assistance we can provide.
Mr. President, to the rapporteurs for the valuable work they have presented.
Colleagues, we are now debating Package Two, after having approved Package Six, following the agreement of almost all Heads of State and Government on two international treaties out of sequence.

community-wide, after many other European regulations have established additional community authorities for banking supervision, stock market oversight, insurance regulation, and managing systemic economic risks.
a deployment of texts and more texts of reports, of proposals that address new economic valuation criteria, new procedures, new processes.
procedures. We must not stop and apply what we already have approved.
In the face of the instability experienced by the European continent, the exact opposite is needed: stability and legal certainty.
We do not need a convoluted series of legal findings.
I don't know, dear colleagues, if I am dreaming.
The situation surrounding the rescue is very concerning.
The Spanish government and the state are assuming private debt as public debt with the new debt, without fully disclosing the truth to Spanish citizens.
The Spanish government has requested aid that it previously claimed it did not want and is presenting it ridiculously as a triumph, as some colleagues already warned in this debate.
There is no triumph, only failure, with Bankia and the like.

I insist, there is no other correct policy for Europe than that sponsored by the French government, behind which we must unite in parliamentary ranks, for we will not emerge from debt without the harmonious growth of all and the collective whole.

Supervision as claimed in both reports, of course, all the supervision that is necessary, but simultaneous indispensable growth, also anti-speculative, just as some of the measures in both reports and other reports as well allude to.
Please, also clarity and transparency, balance, as my colleague Sánchez Presedo mentioned earlier.
Madam President, since I joined this Parliament, I have not ceased to denounce female genital mutilation.
that silent and accepted crime suffered by millions of women and girls around the world - seventy million, I repeat, seventy million.
an unbearable figure for anyone who stops to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which hide behind the disguise of psychological, health, and religious reasons, all of them false.

The truth is that ablation, practiced preferably on girls of fourteen and even one year of age, can lead to death from hemorrhagic collapse and, at best, cause and result in severe psychological sequelae due to the trauma.
From Europe, we must strive with all our might to eradicate this human rights violation, which undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health,
This, ladies and gentlemen, is about abuse, cruelty, torture against girls, and this degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To achieve this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms available to our legal system, and I encourage our judges to take action to prevent genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who carry it out, so that European law speaks with one voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I call on civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but many of us will not stop because we owe it to seventy million mutilated women.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons we approved the dairy package was precisely to adapt the sector towards a market without milk quotas by 2015.

But it is also true that every time this liberalization date approaches, uncertainty in the sector increases due to the lack of a clear exit strategy. The reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection from us in the face of the decision we must make also multiply.

Reasons, for example, such as the belief in maintaining vineyard planting rights or the preservation of sugar quotas, at least until 2020, reasons such as the uncertainty in the sector regarding the real effects of the dairy package and whether

We will have had time to conduct a serious assessment of these issues, and there are also reasons such as the uncertainty surrounding the future of the common agricultural policy and especially its budget, that is, the portion of income that does not come from markets and affects our producers.

Therefore, what are we asking of you, Commissioner, to convey to Mr. Cholos? That we do not pursue a piecemeal policy of dismantling our protection system without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

postpone the end of the quota until 2015, to a date that provides security to the sector and opens up an open and transparent debate on regulatory mechanisms, because markets are still more unfair and producers are increasingly more defenseless.
Mr. President, many members of this Parliament have heard the voice of the citizens, the voice of the street.
Commissioner, you have stated that this is a yes or no agreement.
As members of this Parliament, we too bear responsibility for the yes or the no.
And we say no because this agreement creates confusion, as is evident.
Intellectual property rights and the rights of internet users are not clarified.
internet users, are we concerned about intellectual property rights?
yes
yes, it is ACTA solution.
No, it is not a solution, because there are two issues to address, not a legal matter, but two political issues: a determination to combat counterfeiting and [the second issue].
piracy and other a new legislative framework for the digital environment, which we have repeatedly requested from the Socialist Group, we are asking for it again.
It is your opportunity.
Do not turn your back on society, for tomorrow you will find that there is no way out.
improve, this time it is necessary to emphasize the chaos.
The sense of impotence was so profound that, by necessity, Europe had to react, and it did so for the benefit of all, because the true winner of this past Summit was the euro.
And with this triumph, hope has returned that Europe will overcome its paralysis, moving from reflection to action.
At this summit, Members, it was as necessary to adopt short-term measures to ensure financial stability as it was to implement long-term measures to address the Union's shortcomings.
In this case, the immediate was indispensable to continue working in favor of what is important.
It was imperative to send a message that the euro is a common, irrevocable, and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, decisions as important as empowering the European Stability Mechanism to directly recapitalize banks, which will break the vicious circle between banking debt and sovereign debt, a thesis, by the way, always defended by the current Spanish government.
Furthermore, it will serve to intervene in markets in support of the public debt of countries that meet their public deficit and reform commitments.
Those were necessary decisions to ensure financial stability, which should be, in the short term, the European Union's top priority.
This is not the time, ladies and gentlemen, for certain countries to resort to nationalist maxims and place obstacles in the way.
I have already said it, it is time to bet on Europe.
Spain, Ladies and Gentlemen, is adopting and implementing in record time the most ambitious reform agenda in Spanish democracy, which includes a profound labor reform.
Furthermore, it is implementing a financial reform based on total transparency, thereby demonstrating its commitment to fiscal consolidation and meeting deficit targets.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process towards greater economic integration through four blocks: a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework, and strengthening democratic legitimacy.
Mr. President, in conclusion, the Community first and then the European Union has always been not only about overcoming crises, but also emerging stronger from them.
I am glad that once again we are going to succeed.
Dear colleagues, all our attention is focused on banks, which we continually hear described as the lifeblood of society.
It is likely that this image is accurate, but let us bear in mind that every body is supported by a spine and joints.
Well then, the backbone and joints of that social body we call Europe are precisely its transportation networks and its energy infrastructures.
It is essential, as has been stated this afternoon here in the chamber, to mobilize private financing and, if necessary, public financing.
And, moreover, it is an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt, guaranteed by European institutions, specifically aimed at these purposes, and also open to any investor.
Congratulations to the speakers for their work and also to the Commission for its clear impetus to these projects.

Mr. President, dear Commissioner, Minister, in which I greet the new Presidency, I am a veteran militant of the defunct non-aligned movement led by your country and strongly desire the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

Ladies and Gentlemen, we should seize the opportunity for a broader reform of the Court, perhaps, but the Commission's and my colleague's report's ambitions are very positive and should be supported with the unanimity it received in our Committee.
The agility and efficient functioning of the Court are fundamental, which I question with the new, today delayed, patent jurisdiction.
Congratulations to the opponent. Move forward with the Court's reform.

Mr. President, Commissioner Reding, my country has experienced too many setbacks since the arrival of the Popular Party in government, repeated and continuous attempts to roll back established rights, such as silencing those who dissent, including consumer organizations, among others.
The threat to Facua, trampling on, among others, Articles Sixteen and Seventeen of the Spanish Constitution by the Ministry led by Ms. Mato, is a dangerous assault.

not only to freedom of expression and opinion, but also to the right to a high level of consumer protection, fundamental principles of democracy and enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
I therefore call on the Rajoy government to rectify its decision to outlaw FACUA, and I appeal to the Commission to ensure the protection of

Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by highlighting the excellent work of Mrs Macavan, the rapporteur, as well as the other shadow rapporteurs, in achieving this outcome.
