Mr. President, I would like to once again thank everyone who has made this Directive a reality, the Secretariat, the Commissioner, the rapporteur, all those I may have forgotten, and all the colleagues who have been with us.

I want to say to the victims, all of them, absolutely every single one, without exception, that for us, they and their families have a face, have a name, are real, and it is precisely in their name that we act.

We will work to ensure that this Directive does not remain mere wet ink, but with the commitment and assistance of Commissioner Reding, which I absolutely do not doubt, it will have a swift and effective implementation, which is what we all hope for and expect.

And I am certain that this is a first and important step, to be followed by many others that will open those doors of justice that have been closed to the victims for far too long.
When they ask me in my country what I am doing in Europe, I can say with great pride that I am legislating in favor of victims.
And that work, personally, deeply honors me and gives me a lot of strength to keep working.

I am certain that, with the support and commitment not only of those of us working here in Europe, but also in our respective countries, we will succeed, together with your lordships, in bringing the victims out of this unjust oblivion.

The work of the rapporteur, Mr. President, is very good, but I would like to take this opportunity to say here, in this forum, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can attest.
We forget what Pufendorf already taught, that general laws should be few and their meaning must be correctly understood.
Therefore, those who promote it should use all the clarity that is possible.
And Montesquieu always insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
In other words, we must avoid esoteric jargon, filled with neologisms and unjustified linguistic borrowings, because it creates a sinister web where pitfalls lurk and arbitrariness takes root.
We address very complex matters in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to communicate them to the citizenry in a comprehensible and accessible manner.
It is common for even legal professionals themselves, judges, and lawyers to become despairing when faced with our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way to demonstrate respect for the citizen.

Mr. President, there exists, honorable members, an old principle that has transitioned from the legal to the political realm, and that is pacta sunt servanda, in other words, agreements are meant to be fulfilled.
By this, I refer to the significant measures adopted by the June European Council to address the crisis that affects us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased, and they have positively received decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro irreversibly.
The European Council held last week, ladies and gentlemen, undeniably contains positive aspects. The conclusions on progress towards banking union are satisfactory.
The agreement of the twenty-seven to launch the banking supervisor is also positive. Ultimately, it is appropriate to entrust the launch to the Eurozone's Ministers of Economy.
but it will allow you to make a critical judgment about the biased interpretations that have been made of it in a one-sided manner.

It is not admissible, ladies and gentlemen, to make particular interpretations that could distort the mandate given to the Ministers of Economy. Likewise, we do not applaud the reporting of matters as agreements when they were not even discussed.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism that must cover all financial entities.
A common framework for deposit guarantees and a crisis resolution mechanism are also required.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.

Mr. President, five out of three of the working population are employed in the automotive sector.
The figures speak for themselves.
The decline in sales in the European market, coupled with business strategy, leads to, in general terms, the outsourcing and restructuring of companies.
There is a crisis of overcapacity affecting ten assembly plants and potentially one hundred workers.

Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision. Generally, a short-term perspective prevails, where the main focus is on gaining competitiveness through labor adjustments.

I must tell you that on the same day that Ford announced the suspension of the GEN plant, the Ford company in Valencia was informed in the same corporate communication that its production would be moved to Germany.

Mr. President, today we are debating four reports that represent a revitalization of our common security and defense policy.
It is a clear sign of the belief that our security and defense have a clear European dimension, in contrast to the minority Euroskeptic sectors that also prevail in this Chamber.
The report by Mr. Dan Jan, to whom I would like to express my gratitude for his consensus-seeking spirit during its preparation, contains significant contributions from the Socialist Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
And we would like to see these aspects included in the possible review of the European Defense Strategy.
We have also emphasized that a strong common security and defense policy is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another of the challenges that is taking on significant dimensions for our global security.
It is that of cybersecurity and cyber defense, a report that we are also debating today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European Cybersecurity Strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis, where Member States are being forced to cut their defense budgets, it is when European projects are most needed.
That is why it is more important than ever to strengthen the role of the European Defence Agency, which is currently facing significant challenges.
I conclude by stating that we can relaunch European security and defence, and do so with President Van Rompuy's project for the December 2013 Council.
Many thanks to the four speakers.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, once again, the defense of the general interests upheld by the Commission and Parliament is facing off against national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
With the prior acceptance of the legitimacy of both positions, it is inexcusable not to achieve a balance.
The relevance of the upcoming financial framework is undeniable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on their behalf, reiterate that the Presidency's proposal is, in our view, unacceptable.
A cut of seventy-five million euros from the already inevitably meager proposal by the European Commission is sterile and futile.
And it is not just that—the new direct cut to agricultural and cohesion policies crosses the red line that Spain has been signaling since the beginning of the negotiations.
Ladies and Gentlemen, it is no longer the time to debate a supposed dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create jobs.
And with this budget, one does not get very far. Rather, it constitutes a missile to the waterline.
Ladies and Gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with far fewer resources, especially if what exists is distributed unjustly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that would simply mean the disappearance of growth opportunities and, above all, any trace of solidarity, and this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, which deserves credit for its efforts in outlining a different approach.

And at this point, emphasizing the need for unity and shared efforts, I would like to thank Mr. Barroso for making a forceful statement the other day in Cádiz regarding the interpretation of the Treaties in the event of a secessionist scenario within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as the guardian of the Treaties, that if a part of a Member State secedes as an independent state, it becomes considered a third country and, therefore, will not be affected in any way by the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself.

I hope, Mr. Vice-President, in the absence of the Mr. President, that this can be noted and that this firm and consistent doctrine of the Commission can continue to remain alive for the assurance of all.
